Geometric class field theory and Cartier duality

Justin Campbell and Andreas Hayash
Abstract

We formulate and prove a generalized Albanese property for families of maps from a smooth curve over an arbitrary field into a commutative group stack. Our proof, which is mostly self-contained, employs local-to-global techniques and some new Ext-vanishing results to reduce to the local Cartier self-duality theorem of Contou-Carrére. As a corollary, we reprove local and global geometric class field theory with arbitrary ramification.

1 Introduction

1.1   History of the problem.

Modern geometric class field theory has its origins in the work of Lang and Rosenlicht in the 1950s, summarized in the book by Serre [22]. They reproved Artin reciprocity for function fields using methods from algebraic geometry, emphasizing the role of the Albanese property enjoyed by the Jacobian variety of an algebraic curve.

Later, Deligne and Serre reinterpreted geometric class field theory in terms of étale local systems, so that it could be formulated for curves over any field. The Artin reciprocity isomorphism for function fields over a finite ground field can be recovered from their formulation by passing through the faisceaux-fonctions correspondence. Deligne gave a beautiful geometric proof of the global unramified case, which is to say for local systems on a smooth projective curve (see [18] for an account). After some modification his argument applies to the tamely ramified case ([26],[27]), and recently has been extended to allow arbitrary ramification ([15],[25]).

Meanwhile, local geometric class field theory is not particularly well-documented in the literature. Serre [23] gave an approach to local class field theory for a complete non-archimedean field with algebraically closed residue field of positive characteristic, which was generalized by Hazewinkel [16] to allow any perfect residue field of positive characteristic, and later Suzuki and Yoshida [24] extended this to an arbitrary perfect residue field (see also [28]). This approach has a geometric flavor, with the group of local units in some sense playing the role of local Jacobian. However, the arguments are arithmetic in nature, relying on Galois cohomology and related techniques.

1.2   The generalized Albanese property.

In this paper we formulate and prove a generalized Albanese property in the spirit of Lang and Rosenlicht, valid for maps from a smooth curve over any field into a rather general kind of commutative group stack, which is required only to satisfy a reflexivity property with respect to Cartier duality (Corollary 2.2.1.1). As a consequence, we obtain a strong form of geometric class field theory á là Deligne, allowing local systems with arbitrary ramification (Corollary 2.4.1.1). The Albanese property applies to families of maps over an arbitrary base; in fact, this is crucial for our proof (we work with a curve defined over the ground field, but our methods should extend to the case of a relative curve without too much difficulty).

Cartier duality plays a key role in our approach. Namely, when the target stack is taken to be the classifying stack of the multiplicative group, the generalized Albanese property amounts to a perfect pairing between the Picard stack of the open curve (suitably interpreted) and the stack classifying line bundles on its projective closure with full level structure at the punctures (Theorem 2.2.1). Our proof of the Albanese property in general proceeds by reduction to this case.

Although many special cases were previously known, and the subject is an old one, our main result appears to be new. One possible explanation for this is that the generalized Albanese property for open curves is subtle to formulate in families. The obstruction can be seen in some examples constructed by Bass in 1962 [3], which show that a family of line bundles on an open curve need not extend to its projective closure, even locally on the base. We overcome this difficulty, essentially by systematically excluding such non-extendable families of line bundles. In addition, we show that our Albanese property specializes to the naïve one when the target is a commutative affine group scheme or the classifying stack of a finite abelian group.

1.3   Methods.

We begin by establishing a local Cartier self-duality theorem (Theorem 2.3.1) in the style of Contou-Carrère [9] using the theory of Tate vector bundles and the Beilinson-Kapranov determinant gerbe (see [12],[17], and [4] for background on these notions; this approach is compared to Contou-Carrère’s in Appendix A). Our result strengthens Contou-Carrère’s by also proving that any family of multiplicative line bundles on the group of local units is trivial locally on the base. In fact, we prove a similar vanishing statement for an arbitrary commutative affine group scheme, which surprisingly seems to be new even for the additive group, although many other cases were known previously (see [7]).

Our proof of the local self-duality theorem is carried out factorizably, meaning we consider several points of the curve simultaneously and allow them to move and collide. This allows us to use local-to-global methods when proving the global Cartier self-duality theorem. The other main input for the global theorem is the fact that any family of multiplicative line bundles on the group of global invertible rational functions is trivial locally on the base (Lemma 6.4.2; see [5] Proposition 4.9.1 for a closely related statement). The proof of this global vanishing result in loc. cit. contains a gap, which we address following a suggestion made by Beilinson to the first-named author.

As previously mentioned, we also show that our formulation of the generalized Albanese property implies geometric class field theory with arbitrary ramification (Theorem 2.4.1). The content of this implication is that any family of torsion line bundles on the open curve extends to its projective completion locally on the base. As we explain in Section 9, this follows from recent results of Bouthier and Česnavičius [6].

1.4   Relation to previous work.

In addition to the above-cited works, the formulation of our main theorem was inspired by [11], where a version of the generalized Albanese property is proved in the unramified setting (i.e. for a projective curve). Their hypotheses on the target commutative group stack are rather complicated and seem to be less general than ours, although we are uncertain of the precise relation.

Contou-Carrère proved a version of the Albanese property for an open curve in [10], allowing families of maps into a smooth commutative group scheme. His approach, although different from ours, also emphasizes the role of Cartier duality.

Our approach has also been influenced by Mirković’s conjectural inner homology theory in algebraic geometry (see [20]). Specifically, he has proposed dual homology and cohomology theories on the category of (ind)-schemes with values in commutative group stacks which refine the usual singular theories. Our formulation of geometric class field theory, and in particular the generalized Albanese property, may be viewed as saying that the value of his cohomology theory on a curve is the Picard stack. In particular, the ramified duality statement may be construed as a version of Poincare duality between compactly supported cohomology and homology. One may adopt a similar perspective locally by thinking of the affine Grassmannian as the compactly supported cohomology of a disc.

Let us also comment on the relationship with the geometric Langlands program. Although geometric class field theory can be viewed as a special case of the geometric Langlands correspondence, proposed proofs of the latter (see [14] for a proof sketch in the de Rham setting) take class field theory as an input via the theory of geometric Eisenstein series. Thus the geometric Langlands program does not so much subsume geometric class field theory as rely on it.

We became aware of [15] and [25] during the preparation of this manuscript. They both prove versions of our Corollary 2.4.1.1: Takeuchi proves the isomorphism at the level of geometric points, and Guignard in families (even for a relative curve). Their methods are quite different from ours.

2 Statement of results

2.1   

The letters S𝑆S, T𝑇T, etc. will always denote affine schemes over k𝑘k. We work with stacks in the fppf topology unless otherwise specified. All Picard groupoids and commutative group stacks are assumed to be strictly commutative, i.e. for any point g𝑔g the commutativity constraint g⊗g​→~​g⊗gtensor-producttensor-product𝑔𝑔~→𝑔𝑔g\otimes g\tilde{\to}g\otimes g is required to be the identity map.

Recall that the 2-category of (strictly) commutative group stacks is equivalent to the full subcategory of the derived category of sheaves of abelian groups consisting of complexes concentrated in degrees −11-1 and 00. Accordingly, we can speak of exact triangles of commutative group stacks, etc. See [7] for more details.

Given prestacks Y𝑌Y and Z𝑍Z, we write Map¯⁡(Y,Z)¯Map𝑌𝑍\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(Y,Z) for the internal mapping space, defined by

Map⁡(S,Map¯⁡(Y,Z)):=Map⁡(Y×S,Z).assignMap𝑆¯Map𝑌𝑍Map𝑌𝑆𝑍\operatorname{Map}(S,\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(Y,Z)):=\operatorname{Map}(Y\times S,Z).

Similarly, if G𝐺G and H𝐻H are commutative group stacks then we denote by Hom¯⁡(G,H)¯Hom𝐺𝐻\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G,H) their internal Hom, given on the level of points by

Map⁡(S,Hom¯⁡(G,H)):=HomS⁡(G×S,H×S).assignMap𝑆¯Hom𝐺𝐻subscriptHom𝑆𝐺𝑆𝐻𝑆\operatorname{Map}(S,\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G,H)):=\operatorname{Hom}_{S}(G\times S,H\times S).

In particular, we write

G∗:=Hom¯⁡(G,𝔾m)assignsuperscript𝐺¯Hom𝐺subscript𝔾𝑚G^{*}:=\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G,\mathbb{G}_{m})

and

G∨:=Hom¯⁡(G,B​𝔾m)assignsuperscript𝐺¯Hom𝐺𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚G^{\vee}:=\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G,B\mathbb{G}_{m})

for the Cartier 00-dual and 111-dual, respectively, of G𝐺G. We say that G𝐺G is 00-reflexive, respectively 111-reflexive, if the canonical map G→G∗∗→𝐺superscript𝐺absentG\to G^{**}, respectively G→G∨∨→𝐺superscript𝐺absentG\to G^{\vee\vee}, is an isomorphism.

2.2

Write Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X) for the commutative group stack which parameterizes line bundles on X𝑋X equipped with a trivialization along the “boundary,” i.e. the punctured formal neighborhood of the closed points in X¯∖X¯𝑋𝑋\overline{X}\setminus X.

The stack Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X) receives the Abel-Jacobi map

x𝑥\displaystyle x ↦(𝒪X​(x),1).maps-toabsentsubscript𝒪𝑋𝑥1\displaystyle\mapsto(\mathcal{O}_{X}(x),1).

We define Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) to be the stack parameterizing line bundles on X𝑋X which extend to X¯¯𝑋\overline{X} locally on the base: we call such line bundles extendable. Equivalently Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) is the stack-theoretic image of the forgetful map

Pic⁡(X,∂X)⟶Map¯⁡(X,B​𝔾m).⟶Pic𝑋𝑋¯Map𝑋𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,B\mathbb{G}_{m}).

Of course, if X𝑋X is projective then Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) is the usual Picard stack. Note that if S𝑆S is regular, then all line bundles on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S are extendable.

Let G𝐺G be a 111-reflexive commutative group stack. A map X×S→G→𝑋𝑆𝐺X\times S\to G will be called B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-extendable if, for any map T→S→𝑇𝑆T\to S and any homomorphism G×T→B​𝔾m×T→𝐺𝑇𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚𝑇G\times T\to B\mathbb{G}_{m}\times T over T𝑇T, the resulting line bundle

X×T⟶G×T⟶B​𝔾m⟶𝑋𝑇𝐺𝑇⟶𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚X\times T\longrightarrow G\times T\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}

is extendable. We write

Map¯(X,G)ext⊂Map¯(X,G)\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,G)^{\operatorname{ext}}\subset\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,G)

for the substack consisting of B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-extendable maps. Observe that we have a tautological identification

Map¯(X,G)ext=Hom¯(G∨,Pic(X)).\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,G)^{\operatorname{ext}}=\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Pic}(X)).

In particular Map¯(X,B𝔾m)ext=Pic(X)\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,B\mathbb{G}_{m})^{\operatorname{ext}}=\operatorname{Pic}(X).

We can now state our main theorems.

Theorem 2.2.1.

Restriction along AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X} induces an isomorphism

Pic(X,∂X)∨⟶~Pic(X).\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)^{\vee}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Pic}(X).

Moreover, the commutative group stacks Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X) and Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) are 111-reflexive.

See Section 7.2 for the proof. Note that the theorem says in particular that we have a perfect pairing

⟨,]X:Pic(X,∂X)×Pic(X)⟶B𝔾m.\langle\,,\,]_{X}:\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X)\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}.

The generalized Albanese property, stated as follows, follows from Theorem 2.2.1 by a formal argument.

Corollary 2.2.1.1.

For any 111-reflexive commutative group stack G𝐺G, restriction along AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X} induces an isomorphism

Hom¯(Pic(X,∂X),G)⟶~Map¯(X,G)ext.\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X),G)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,G)^{\operatorname{ext}}.

This corollary is also proved in Section 7.2. Note that the case G=B​𝔾m𝐺𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚G=B\mathbb{G}_{m} recovers the theorem.

2.3   

Our proof of Theorem 2.2.1 is by local-to-global methods. Fixing a closed point x𝑥x in X𝑋X, we consider the formal disk Dxsubscript𝐷𝑥D_{x} and the punctured disk D̊xsubscript̊𝐷𝑥\mathring{D}_{x} centered at x𝑥x.

For any prestack Y𝑌Y, we will write aff⁡(Y):=Spec⁡Γ​(Y,𝒪Y)assignaff𝑌SpecΓ𝑌subscript𝒪𝑌\operatorname{aff}(Y):=\operatorname{Spec}\Gamma(Y,\mathcal{O}_{Y}). Let

D̊x,S:=aff⁡(Dx×S)∖({x}×S).assignsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆affsubscript𝐷𝑥𝑆𝑥𝑆\mathring{D}_{x,S}:=\operatorname{aff}(D_{x}\times S)\setminus(\{x\}\times S).

We abuse notation by writing Map¯⁡(D̊x,Y)¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑌\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},Y) for the modified mapping prestack defined by

Map⁡(S,Map¯⁡(D̊x,Y)):=Map⁡(D̊x,S,Y).assignMap𝑆¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑌Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆𝑌\operatorname{Map}(S,\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},Y)):=\operatorname{Map}(\mathring{D}_{x,S},Y).

The role of Jacobian of D̊xsubscript̊𝐷𝑥\mathring{D}_{x} is played by the group

𝔏x​𝔾m:=Map¯⁡(D̊x,𝔾m)assignsubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m}:=\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},\mathbb{G}_{m})

of formal loops into 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m} centered at x𝑥x. We write

Pic⁡(D̊x):=B​𝔏x​𝔾m,assignPicsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵subscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x}):=B\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m},

so analogously to the global situation we have an inclusion

Pic⁡(D̊x)⟶Map¯⁡(D̊x,B​𝔾m)⟶Picsubscript̊𝐷𝑥¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x})\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},B\mathbb{G}_{m})

whose image consists of families satisfying an extendability condition.

The group stacks 𝔏x​𝔾msubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m} and Pic⁡(D̊x)Picsubscript̊𝐷𝑥\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x}) generalize in a straightforward fashion to the case where x𝑥x is replaced by a finite subset of X𝑋X, and continue to make sense in families as the points move and collide. Moreover, these spaces admit natural factorization structures which reflect their local nature. In Section 4 we recall how this structure is encoded using the Ran space of X𝑋X.

The key local input to our theorem is the pairing

⟨,]D̊x:Pic(D̊x)×𝔏x𝔾m⟶B𝔾m,\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{x}}:\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x})\times\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m},

obtained by delooping the 222-cocyle

attached to the Tate extension of 𝔏x​𝔾msubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m}. In Section 4 we review the construction of this pairing using determinant gerbes of Tate vector spaces.

Corollary 2.3.1.1.

There is a unique natural isomorphism

See Corollary 5.4.1.1 for a more precise formulation and its proof.

Our characterization of the isomorphism in Corollary 2.3.1.1 is more complicated than that of the analogous global isomorphism in Corollary 2.2.1.1, since the former is not given by restriction along an Abel-Jacobi map

D̊x⟶𝔏x​𝔾m.⟶subscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathring{D}_{x}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m}.

However, such a map can be constructed after modifying 𝔏x​𝔾msubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m} suitably. This was the approach of Contou-Carrère, which we compare with ours in the appendix. The construction is somewhat awkward: the authors expect that a conceptual explanation will probably involve some kind of rigid-analytic or adic geometry.

2.4   

In order to apply our results to geometric class field theory, we take G=B​A𝐺𝐵𝐴G=BA where A𝐴A is a constant finite abelian group. It turns out the the B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-extendability condition is superfluous in this case.

Theorem 2.4.1.

The inclusions

Map¯(X,BA)ext⟶Map¯(X,BA)\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,BA)^{\operatorname{ext}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,BA)

and

Map¯(D̊x,BA)ext⟶Map¯(D̊x,BA)\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},BA)^{\operatorname{ext}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},BA)

are isomorphisms.

See Section 9.2 for the proof. Combining the theorem with Corollary 2.2.1.1, we immediately obtain the following version of global geometric class field theory with arbitrary ramification.

Corollary 2.4.1.1.

Restriction along AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X} induces an isomorphism

Hom¯⁡(Pic⁡(X,∂X),B​A)​⟶~​Map¯⁡(X,B​A).¯HomPic𝑋𝑋𝐵𝐴~⟶¯Map𝑋𝐵𝐴\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X),BA)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(X,BA).

Similarly, Theorem 2.4.1 combined with Corollary 2.3.1.1 yields local geometric class field theory.

Corollary 2.4.1.2.

When G=B​A𝐺𝐵𝐴G=BA, the isomorphism of Corollary 2.3.1.1 specializes to an isomorphism

Hom¯⁡(𝔏x​𝔾m,B​A)​⟶~​Map¯⁡(D̊x,B​A),¯Homsubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚𝐵𝐴~⟶¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵𝐴\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m},BA)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},BA),

natural in A𝐴A.

Passing to k𝑘k-points, we in particular obtain isomorphisms

Hom⁡(Pic⁡(X,∂X),B​A)​⟶~​Map⁡(X,B​A)HomPic𝑋𝑋𝐵𝐴~⟶Map𝑋𝐵𝐴\operatorname{Hom}(\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X),BA)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Map}(X,BA)

and

Hom⁡(𝔏x​𝔾m,B​A)​⟶~​Map⁡(D̊x,B​A),Homsubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚𝐵𝐴~⟶Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵𝐴\operatorname{Hom}(\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m},BA)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Map}(\mathring{D}_{x},BA),

natural in A𝐴A. In the case where k𝑘k is finite, standard arguments using the trace of Frobenius construction then imply the classical Artin reciprocity isomorphisms for the function field of X𝑋X and its completions.

3 Tate vector bundles

3.1   

Below we recall the basic theory of Tate vector bundles and their determinant gerbes, developed in [4] and [12]. Writing S=Spec⁡A𝑆Spec𝐴S=\operatorname{Spec}A, we will consider topological A𝐴A-modules which are complete, Hausdorff, and admit a base of open neighborhoods of 00 consisting of A𝐴A-submodules. Given a homomorphism A→B→𝐴𝐵A\to B, restriction of scalars preserves such topological modules, and moreover admits a left adjoint given by the completed extension of scalars M↦B​⊗^A​Mmaps-to𝑀𝐵subscript^tensor-product𝐴𝑀M\mapsto B\widehat{\otimes}_{A}M.

A discrete Tate vector bundle on S𝑆S is a projective A𝐴A-module. A topological A𝐴A-module is called a linearly compact Tate vector bundle on S𝑆S if it is isomorphic to the topological A𝐴A-dual of a projective A𝐴A-module. An elementary Tate vector bundle on S𝑆S is a topological A𝐴A-module isomorphic to one of the form P⊕Qdirect-sum𝑃𝑄P\oplus Q where P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q are discrete and linearly compact, respectively. A Tate vector bundle on S𝑆S is a topological A𝐴A-module which is a direct summand of an elementary Tate vector bundle. It is shown in [12] that any Tate vector bundle is elementary locally in the Nisnevich topology (in particular, locally in the étale topology).

A lattice in a Tate vector bundle V𝑉V is an open and linearly compact submodule L⊂V𝐿𝑉L\subset V such that V/L𝑉𝐿V/L is projective (in loc. cit. it is called a coprojective lattice). Note that a Tate vector bundle is elementary if and only it admits a lattice.

3.2   

A key role is played by the following construction from [4]. Consider the category Proj(S)∞\operatorname{Proj}(S)^{\infty} whose objects are projective A𝐴A-modules and whose morphisms are given by the formula

HomProj(S)∞⁡(P,Q):=HomA⁡(P,Q)/HomAf⁡(P,Q),\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Proj}(S)^{\infty}}(P,Q):=\operatorname{Hom}_{A}(P,Q)/\operatorname{Hom}_{A}^{f}(P,Q),

where HomAf⁡(P,Q)superscriptsubscriptHom𝐴𝑓𝑃𝑄\operatorname{Hom}_{A}^{f}(P,Q) consists of A𝐴A-linear maps P→Q→𝑃𝑄P\to Q whose image is contained in a finitely generated submodule. Denoting by Proj⁡(S)Proj𝑆\operatorname{Proj}(S) the category of projective A𝐴A-modules, we therefore have a canonical functor Proj(S)→Proj(S)∞\operatorname{Proj}(S)\to\operatorname{Proj}(S)^{\infty}.

A morphism φ:P→Q:𝜑→𝑃𝑄\varphi:P\to Q in Proj⁡(S)Proj𝑆\operatorname{Proj}(S) is called Fredholm if its image φ∞superscript𝜑\varphi^{\infty} in Proj(S)∞\operatorname{Proj}(S)^{\infty} is an isomorphism. In loc. cit. Proposition 2.7, the authors construct a determinant line bundle det(φ∞)superscript𝜑\det(\varphi^{\infty}) on S𝑆S (there denoted by det(Q,P,φ∞)𝑄𝑃superscript𝜑\det(Q,P,\varphi^{\infty})) attached functorially to any Fredholm operator φ𝜑\varphi. This line bundle depends only on φ∞superscript𝜑\varphi^{\infty}, its formation is compatible with base change, and if P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q have finite rank then we have det(φ∞)=(detP)−1⊗detQsuperscript𝜑tensor-productsuperscript𝑃1𝑄\det(\varphi^{\infty})=(\det P)^{-1}\otimes\det Q.

This allows us to construct the relative determinant line of two lattices L1,L2⊂Vsubscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2𝑉L_{1},L_{2}\subset V. Write π:V→V/L2:𝜋→𝑉𝑉subscript𝐿2\pi:V\to V/L_{2} for the projection and choose a splitting σ:V/L1→V:𝜎→𝑉subscript𝐿1𝑉\sigma:V/L_{1}\to V of the other projection. Then (π∘σ)∞superscript𝜋𝜎(\pi\circ\sigma)^{\infty} does not depend on the choice of σ𝜎\sigma, and we put

det(L1,L2):=det((π∘σ)∞),assignsubscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2superscript𝜋𝜎\det(L_{1},L_{2}):=\det((\pi\circ\sigma)^{\infty}),

a line bundle on S𝑆S.

If L1⊃L2subscript𝐿2subscript𝐿1L_{1}\supset L_{2} then L1/L2subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2L_{1}/L_{2} is projective of finite rank and det(L1,L2)=det(L1/L2)subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2\det(L_{1},L_{2})=\det(L_{1}/L_{2}). For any three lattices L1,L2,L3⊂Vsubscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2subscript𝐿3𝑉L_{1},L_{2},L_{3}\subset V we have a canonical isomorphism

det(L1,L2)⊗det(L2,L3)​⟶~​det(L1,L3),tensor-productsubscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2subscript𝐿2subscript𝐿3~⟶subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿3\det(L_{1},L_{2})\otimes\det(L_{2},L_{3})\tilde{\longrightarrow}\det(L_{1},L_{3}),

and these isomorphisms satisfy the obvious cocycle condition.

3.3   

Following [12], to any Tate vector bundle V𝑉V we attach its determinant gerbe D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V), a 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m}-gerbe (a.k.a. B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-torsor) on S𝑆S. A section of D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V) is a (weak) determinant theory d𝑑d on V𝑉V, which assigns to every lattice L⊂V𝐿𝑉L\subset V a line bundle d​(L)𝑑𝐿d(L) equipped with isomorphisms

d​(L1)⊗det(L1,L2)​⟶~​d​(L2),tensor-product𝑑subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿2~⟶𝑑subscript𝐿2d(L_{1})\otimes\det(L_{1},L_{2})\tilde{\longrightarrow}d(L_{2}),

compatible with the transitivity isomorphisms for the relative determinant. Formation of the determinant gerbe is compatible with base change.

Any lattice L⊂V𝐿𝑉L\subset V determines a determinant theory L′↦det(L,L′)maps-tosuperscript𝐿′𝐿superscript𝐿′L^{\prime}\mapsto\det(L,L^{\prime}) on V𝑉V, and hence a section of D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V). In particular the gerbe D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V) is trivial Nisnevich locally on S𝑆S.

The construction V↦D​(V)maps-to𝑉𝐷𝑉V\mapsto D(V) is functorial in isomorphisms. In particular, if φ𝜑\varphi is a continuous automorphism of the Tate vector bundle V𝑉V, it determines an automorphism D​(φ;V)𝐷𝜑𝑉D(\varphi;V) of D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V), which is just a line bundle on S𝑆S. If L⊂V𝐿𝑉L\subset V is a lattice then we have

D​(φ;V)=det(φ​(L),L).𝐷𝜑𝑉𝜑𝐿𝐿\textstyle D(\varphi;V)=\det(\varphi(L),L).

Moreover, we have canonical isomorphisms

D​(φ1∘φ2;V)​⟶~​D​(φ1;V)⊗D​(φ2;V)tensor-product𝐷subscript𝜑1subscript𝜑2𝑉~⟶𝐷subscript𝜑1𝑉𝐷subscript𝜑2𝑉\textstyle D(\varphi_{1}\circ\varphi_{2};V)\tilde{\longrightarrow}D(\varphi_{1};V)\otimes D(\varphi_{2};V)

satisfying the obvious compatibilities.

3.4   

If V𝑉V is a Tate vector bundle on S=Spec⁡A𝑆Spec𝐴S=\operatorname{Spec}A, we call a submodule M⊂V𝑀𝑉M\subset V a colattice if it is complementary to a lattice. In particular M𝑀M is discrete and projective, and V/M𝑉𝑀V/M is linearly compact.

We would like to attach to a pair of colattices M1,M2⊂Vsubscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2𝑉M_{1},M_{2}\subset V their relative determinant line bundle det(M1,M2)subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2\det(M_{1},M_{2}) on S𝑆S, in much the same way as for lattices. In particular we desire that if M1⊃M2subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀1M_{1}\supset M_{2} then we have det(M1,M2)=det(M1/M2)subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2\det(M_{1},M_{2})=\det(M_{1}/M_{2}), and that we have transitivity isomorphisms satisfying a cocycle condition.

Denote by ι:M1→V:𝜄→subscript𝑀1𝑉\iota:M_{1}\to V the inclusion and choose a retract ρ:V→M2:𝜌→𝑉subscript𝑀2\rho:V\to M_{2} of the other inclusion. Then (ρ∘ι)∞superscript𝜌𝜄(\rho\circ\iota)^{\infty} does not depend on the choice of ρ𝜌\rho, and we define

det(M1,M2):=det((ρ∘ι)∞).assignsubscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2superscript𝜌𝜄\det(M_{1},M_{2}):=\det((\rho\circ\iota)^{\infty}).

Finally, we also introduce the relative determinant line of a lattice L⊂V𝐿𝑉L\subset V and a colattice M⊂V𝑀𝑉M\subset V. Denote by ι:M→V:𝜄→𝑀𝑉\iota:M\to V the inclusion and π:V→V/L:𝜋→𝑉𝑉𝐿\pi:V\to V/L the projection. We define

det(M,L):=det((π∘ι)∞)assign𝑀𝐿superscript𝜋𝜄\det(M,L):=\det((\pi\circ\iota)^{\infty})

and

det(L,M):=det(M,L)−1.assign𝐿𝑀superscript𝑀𝐿1\det(L,M):=\det(M,L)^{-1}.

Note that we have transitivity isomorphisms

det(M,L)⊗det(L,L′)​⟶~​det(M,L′)tensor-product𝑀𝐿𝐿superscript𝐿′~⟶𝑀superscript𝐿′\det(M,L)\otimes\det(L,L^{\prime})\tilde{\longrightarrow}\det(M,L^{\prime})

and

det(M′,M)⊗det(M,L)​⟶~​det(M′,L)tensor-productsuperscript𝑀′𝑀𝑀𝐿~⟶superscript𝑀′𝐿\det(M^{\prime},M)\otimes\det(M,L)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\det(M^{\prime},L)

satisfying the obvious compatibility conditions. In particular a choice of colattice determines a determinant theory on V𝑉V, i.e. trivializes the determinant gerbe D​(V)𝐷𝑉D(V).

4 The local pairing

4.1   

Recall that the Ran space, which we denote by RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, is the prestack which parameterizes nonempty finite subsets of X𝑋X. It can be written as

Ran=colim𝐼​XI,Ran𝐼colimsuperscript𝑋𝐼\operatorname{Ran}=\underset{I}{\operatorname{colim}}\ X^{I},

where the colimit is taken over the category of nonempty finite sets and surjective maps. In particular, a point S→Ran→𝑆RanS\to\operatorname{Ran} factors through a map xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} for some nonempty finite set I𝐼I.

We denote by DRansubscript𝐷RanD_{\operatorname{Ran}} the multidisk over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, defined as the subspace of X×Ran𝑋RanX\times\operatorname{Ran} consisting of pairs (x,xI):S→X×Ran:𝑥subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆𝑋Ran(x,x_{I}):S\to X\times\operatorname{Ran} such that

Γx⊂DxI:=(X×S)^ΓxI.subscriptΓ𝑥subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼assignsubscript^𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\Gamma_{x}\subset D_{x_{I}}:=\widehat{(X\times S)}_{\Gamma_{x_{I}}}.

Here we use the standard notation

ΓxI:=⋃i∈IΓxiassignsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝑖𝐼subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝑖\Gamma_{x_{I}}:=\bigcup_{i\in I}\Gamma_{x_{i}}

for the union of the graphs.

For any prestack Y𝑌Y over X𝑋X we can form the associated space of arcs 𝔏Ran+​Ysubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y, a prestack over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}. A point S→𝔏Ran+​Y→𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌S\to\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y consists of xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} and a map DxI→Y→subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑌D_{x_{I}}\to Y over X𝑋X. If Y𝑌Y is constant, i.e. has the form Z×X𝑍𝑋Z\times X, we will abuse notation by writing 𝔏Ran+​Zsubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑍\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Z rather than 𝔏Ran+​(Z×X)subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑍𝑋\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(Z\times X).

Let us recall the factorization structure on the arc space. Writing

(Ran×Ran)disj⊂Ran×RansubscriptRanRandisjRanRan(\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran})_{\operatorname{disj}}\subset\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran}

for the set of pairs (xI,yJ)subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝑦𝐽(x_{I},y_{J}) such that ΓxI∩ΓyJ=∅subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼subscriptΓsubscript𝑦𝐽\Gamma_{x_{I}}\cap\Gamma_{y_{J}}=\varnothing, this structure consists of isomorphisms

(Ran×Ran)disj×Ran𝔏Ran+​Y​⟶~​(Ran×Ran)disj×Ran×Ran(𝔏Ran+​Y×𝔏Ran+​Y),subscriptRanRansubscriptRansubscriptRanRandisjsubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌~⟶subscriptRanRandisjsubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌(\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran})_{\operatorname{disj}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y\tilde{\longrightarrow}(\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran})_{\operatorname{disj}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran}}(\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y\times\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y),

where the the map (Ran×Ran)disj→Ran→subscriptRanRandisjRan(\operatorname{Ran}\times\operatorname{Ran})_{\operatorname{disj}}\to\operatorname{Ran} in the first fiber product is given by union of finite subsets of X𝑋X. These isomorphisms satisfy natural associativity and commutativity conditions.

The arc space also admits an evident counital structure compatible with factorization, consisting of a compatible collection of maps

𝔏XI+​Y⟶XI×XJ𝔏XJ+​Y⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼𝑌subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝐽superscript𝑋𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐽𝑌\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}Y\longrightarrow X^{I}\times_{X^{J}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{J}}Y

for every injection of (possibly empty) finite sets J→I→𝐽𝐼J\to I (here we put 𝔏X∅+​Y:=Spec⁡kassignsubscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝑌Spec𝑘\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{\varnothing}}Y:=\operatorname{Spec}k). These maps are isomorphisms in the formal neighborhood of the diagonal (as pointed out in [21] Remark 5.2.2, this is equivalent to the fact that the 𝔏XI+​Ysubscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼𝑌\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}Y assemble into a space over RanRan\operatorname{Ran} in the sense of derived algebraic geometry).

4.2   

Given xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}, we define the associated punctured multidisk by

D̊xI:=aff⁡(DxI)∖ΓxI.assignsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼affsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}:=\operatorname{aff}(D_{x_{I}})\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}}.

In particular, we have maps

DxI⟶aff⁡(DxI)⟵D̊xI.⟶subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼affsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼⟵subscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{aff}(D_{x_{I}})\longleftarrow\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}.

If Y𝑌Y is an affine scheme, we define the associated loop space: a point S→𝔏Ran​Y→𝑆subscript𝔏Ran𝑌S\to\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y consists of xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} along with a map D̊xI→Y→subscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑌\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}\to Y. Similarly to 𝔏Ran+​Ysubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y, the prestack 𝔏Ran​Ysubscript𝔏Ran𝑌\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y is equipped with a natural factorization structure. Since

Map⁡(DxI,Y)=Map⁡(aff⁡(DxI),Y),Mapsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑌Mapaffsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑌\operatorname{Map}(D_{x_{I}},Y)=\operatorname{Map}(\operatorname{aff}(D_{x_{I}}),Y),

we have a canonical embedding of factorization spaces

𝔏Ran+​Y⟶𝔏Ran​Y.⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌subscript𝔏Ran𝑌\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y.

4.3   

Observe that the functors Y↦𝔏Ran+​Y,𝔏Ran​Ymaps-to𝑌subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ran𝑌subscript𝔏Ran𝑌Y\mapsto\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y,\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}Y from affine schemes to factorization spaces preserve products. In particular, the factorization spaces 𝔏Ran+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m} and 𝔏Ran​𝔾msubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m} have compatible structures of commutative groups over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}.

In what follows we will consider the commutative group prestack

Pic(D)Ran:=BRan𝔏+𝔾m.\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}:=B_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}\mathbb{G}_{m}.

One checks using the smoothness of 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m} that the canonical map

Pic(D)Ran⟶𝔏Ran+B𝔾m\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}B\mathbb{G}_{m}

is an isomorphism. That is, a point of Pic(D)xI\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{x_{I}} can be viewed as a line bundle on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}, and any such line bundle is trivial locally on S𝑆S.

We similarly define

Pic(D̊)Ran:=BRan𝔏Ran𝔾m.\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}:=B_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}.

A point of Pic(D̊)xI\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{x_{I}} can be viewed as a line bundle on D̊xIsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}} which is trivial locally on S𝑆S. It is well-known that the restriction map

Map⁡(aff⁡(DxI),B​𝔾m)⟶Map⁡(DxI,B​𝔾m)⟶Mapaffsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚Mapsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{Map}(\operatorname{aff}(D_{x_{I}}),B\mathbb{G}_{m})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Map}(D_{x_{I}},B\mathbb{G}_{m})

is an isomorphism (see [13] Lemma 1.1.2), so we can equivalently view Pic(D̊)xI\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{x_{I}} as the stack of line bundles on D̊xIsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}} which, locally on S𝑆S, extend to DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}} (or rather extend to a line bundle on aff⁡(DxI)affsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\operatorname{aff}(D_{x_{I}}), which is the same as a line bundle on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}). In these terms, the homomorphism

Pic(D)Ran⟶Pic(D̊)Ran\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}

induced by 𝔏Ran+​𝔾m→𝔏Ran​𝔾m→subscriptsuperscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚subscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\to\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m} corresponds to restriction of line bundles.

4.4   

We now introduce the local pairing

⟨,]D̊Ran:Pic(D̊)Ran×Ran𝔏Ran𝔾m⟶B𝔾m.\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}:\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}.

The determinant gerbe construction determines the morphism of group prestacks over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}

𝔏Ran​𝔾msubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\displaystyle\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m} ⟶B​𝔾m×Ran⟶absent𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚Ran\displaystyle\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}\times\operatorname{Ran}
(xI,f)subscript𝑥𝐼𝑓\displaystyle(x_{I},f) ↦(D​(f;KxI),xI),maps-toabsent𝐷𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝑥𝐼\displaystyle\mapsto\textstyle(D(f;K_{x_{I}}),x_{I}),

where we view

KxI:=Γ​(D̊xI,𝒪)assignsubscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝒪K_{x_{I}}:=\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{O})

as a Tate vector bundle on S𝑆S.

Crucially, this is not a morphism of commutative group prestacks. It gives rise to a central extension

1⟶𝔾m×Ran⟶(𝔏Ran​𝔾m)♭⟶𝔏Ran​𝔾m⟶1,⟶1subscript𝔾𝑚Ran⟶superscriptsubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚♭⟶subscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚⟶11\longrightarrow\mathbb{G}_{m}\times\operatorname{Ran}\longrightarrow(\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m})^{\flat}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow 1,

which in turn determines the commutator pairing

𝔏Ran​𝔾m×Ran𝔏Ran​𝔾m⟶𝔾m,⟶subscriptRansubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚subscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\mathbb{G}_{m}, (4.4.1)

often referred to as the Contou-Carrère pairing (see also Section 3 of [4] for a similar construction of this pairing). Evidently (4.4.1) is bilinear and skew-symmetric. In the appendix we show that at a fixed point in X𝑋X, this pairing agrees with the one actually introduced by Contou-Carrère in [9].

Finally, we define the local pairing

⟨,]D̊Ran:Pic(D̊)Ran×Ran𝔏Ran𝔾m⟶B𝔾m\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}:\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}

by delooping (4.4.1) in the first variable.

Proposition 4.4.1.

The pairing ⟨,]D̊Ran\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is given by the formula

⟨ℒ,f]D̊Ran=D​(f;Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ))−1⊗D​(f;KxI)subscriptℒ𝑓subscript̊𝐷Rantensor-product𝐷superscript𝑓Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ1𝐷𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼\textstyle\langle\mathcal{L},f]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}=D(f;\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))^{-1}\otimes D(f;K_{x_{I}})

where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is an extendable line bundle on D̊xIsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}} and f:D̊xI→𝔾m:𝑓→subscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚f:\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}\to\mathbb{G}_{m}.

Proof.

The displayed formula determines a homomorphism

𝔏Ran𝔾m⟶Map¯Ran,∙(Pic(D̊)Ran,B𝔾m×Ran)≅Hom¯Ran(𝔏Ran𝔾m,𝔾m×Ran),\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}_{\operatorname{Ran},\bullet}(\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}},B\mathbb{G}_{m}\times\operatorname{Ran})\cong\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m},\mathbb{G}_{m}\times\operatorname{Ran}), (4.4.2)

which we must show agrees with (4.4.1).

Applying the pairing (4.4.1) to f,g:D̊xI→𝔾m:𝑓𝑔→subscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚f,g:\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}\to\mathbb{G}_{m} yields the automorphism

D​(f​g,KxI)𝐷𝑓𝑔subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼\displaystyle\textstyle D(fg,K_{x_{I}}) ⟶~​D​(f,KxI)⊗D​(g,KxI)tensor-product~⟶𝐷𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼𝐷𝑔subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\textstyle D(f,K_{x_{I}})\otimes D(g,K_{x_{I}})

⟶~​D​(g​f,KxI)=D​(f​g,KxI),~⟶𝐷𝑔𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼𝐷𝑓𝑔subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\textstyle D(gf,K_{x_{I}})=D(fg,K_{x_{I}}),

interpreted as an invertible function on S𝑆S.

On the other hand, the pairing (4.4.2) applied to f,g𝑓𝑔f,g gives the invertible function on S𝑆S corresponding to the automorphism

D​(f,KxI)​⟶~𝑔​D​(g​f​g−1,KxI)=D​(f,KxI).𝐷𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼𝑔~⟶𝐷𝑔𝑓superscript𝑔1subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼𝐷𝑓subscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝐼D(f,K_{x_{I}})\overset{g}{\tilde{\longrightarrow}}D(gfg^{-1},K_{x_{I}})=D(f,K_{x_{I}}).

By inspection, these functions agree. ∎

4.5   

Let us recall the definition of the Beilinson-Drinfeld affine Grassmannian Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} for 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m}. An S𝑆S-point of Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} consists of xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}, a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, and a trivialization of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} over (X×S)∖ΓxI𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼(X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}}.

By the Beauville-Laszlo theorem, a point of Gr(D)xI\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{x_{I}} can equivalently be described as a line bundle on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}} together with a trivialization over D̊xIsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}. In particular, we have a short exact sequence

1⟶𝔏Ran+𝔾m⟶𝔏Ran𝔾m⟶Gr(D)Ran⟶11\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow 1

of fppf sheaves relative to RanRan\operatorname{Ran} (i.e. the fibers over any xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} form a short exact sequence of fppf sheaves of abelian groups over S𝑆S).

As is well-known, the space Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} admits a natural factorization structure. Moreover Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} admits a unital structure compatible with factorization. This structure consists of a compatible system of maps

XI×XJGr(D)XJ⟶Gr(D)XIX^{I}\times_{X^{J}}\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{X^{J}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{X^{I}}

over XIsuperscript𝑋𝐼X^{I} for every injection of (possibly empty) finite sets J→I→𝐽𝐼J\to I.

4.6   

We also consider the submonoid Gr+(D)Ran⊂Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\subset\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} consisting of points where the given section extends to X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, possibly with zeros.

Proposition 4.6.1.

The inclusion Gr+(D)Ran→Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\to\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} realizes the latter as the group completion of the former over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}.

Proof.

Fix xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}, a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, and a nonvanishing section σ𝜎\sigma of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} defined away from ΓxIsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\Gamma_{x_{I}}. Viewing ΓxIsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\Gamma_{x_{I}} as an effective Cartier divisor, we see that

σ∈Γ​(X×S,ℒ​(n⋅ΓxI))𝜎Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ⋅𝑛subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\sigma\in\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}(n\cdot\Gamma_{x_{I}}))

for n≫0much-greater-than𝑛0n\gg 0. Thus we obtain the required factorization

(ℒ,σ)=(ℒ​(n⋅ΓxI),σ)⊗(𝒪X×S​(n⋅ΓxI),1)−1.ℒ𝜎tensor-productℒ⋅𝑛subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼𝜎superscriptsubscript𝒪𝑋𝑆⋅𝑛subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼11(\mathcal{L},\sigma)=(\mathcal{L}(n\cdot\Gamma_{x_{I}}),\sigma)\otimes(\mathcal{O}_{X\times S}(n\cdot\Gamma_{x_{I}}),1)^{-1}.

∎

Denote by Div+(D)Ran\operatorname{Div}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} the space of effective relative Cartier divisors on DRansubscript𝐷RanD_{\operatorname{Ran}}, a sheaf of commutative monoids relative to RanRan\operatorname{Ran}. A point S→Div+(D)RanS\to\operatorname{Div}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} consists of a point xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} of RanRan\operatorname{Ran} together with an effective divisor on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S relative to S𝑆S which is contained in DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}. Note that Div+(D)XI\operatorname{Div}_{+}(D)_{X^{I}} is a scheme for all I𝐼I, with connected components Div+d(D)XI\operatorname{Div}^{d}_{+}(D)_{X^{I}} labeled by d≥0𝑑0d\geq 0. It is generally highly reducible and nonreduced.

We have a tautological isomorphism

Div+(D)Ran\displaystyle\operatorname{Div}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} ⟶~Gr+(D)Ran\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} (4.6.1)
(xI,Z)subscript𝑥𝐼𝑍\displaystyle(x_{I},Z) ↦(xI,𝒪X×S​(Z),1).maps-toabsentsubscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝒪𝑋𝑆𝑍1\displaystyle\mapsto(x_{I},\mathcal{O}_{X\times S}(Z),1).

In what follows, we will use this identification without comment and view points of Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} as Cartier divisors when convenient. We write Gr+d(D)XI:=Div+d(D)XI\operatorname{Gr}^{d}_{+}(D)_{X^{I}}:=\operatorname{Div}^{d}_{+}(D)_{X^{I}}, etc.

4.7   

Given a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}, note that Γ​(DxI,ℒ)Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}) is a lattice in the Tate vector bundle Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ)Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}) (the claim is local on S𝑆S, hence reduces to the case ℒ=𝒪ℒ𝒪\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}).

Proposition 4.7.1.

The restricted pairing

Pic(D)Ran×Ran𝔏Ran+𝔾m⟶Pic(D̊)Ran×Ran𝔏Ran𝔾m→⟨,]D̊RanB𝔾m\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\xrightarrow{\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}}B\mathbb{G}_{m}

is canonically trivial, hence determines a pairing

⟨,]DRan:Pic(D)Ran×RanGr(D)Ran⟶B𝔾m.\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}:\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}.

⟨ℒ,Z]DRan=det(Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ​(Z)))−1⊗det(Γ​(DxI,𝒪),Γ​(DxI,𝒪​(Z))),subscriptℒ𝑍subscript𝐷Rantensor-productsuperscriptΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍1Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝒪Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝒪𝑍\langle\mathcal{L},Z]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}=\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)))^{-1}\otimes\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{O}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{O}(Z))),

or when Z𝑍Z is effective by

⟨ℒ,Z]DRan=detΓ​(Z,ℒ)⊗(detΓ​(Z,𝒪))−1.subscriptℒ𝑍subscript𝐷Rantensor-productΓ𝑍ℒsuperscriptΓ𝑍𝒪1\langle\mathcal{L},Z]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}=\det\Gamma(Z,\mathcal{L})\otimes(\det\Gamma(Z,\mathcal{O}))^{-1}.
Proof.

Fix xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}, a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}, and f:DxI→𝔾m:𝑓→subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚f:D_{x_{I}}\to\mathbb{G}_{m}. Then the line

D​(f;Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ))=det(f​Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ))=det(Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ))𝐷𝑓Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑓Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒD(f;\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))=\det(f\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))=\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))

is canonically trivial. The previous proposition yields a trivialization of the line ⟨ℒ|D̊xI,f]D̊Ransubscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑓subscript̊𝐷Ran\langle\mathcal{L}|_{\mathring{D}_{x_{I}}},f]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}.

The formulas in question follow from the observation that for Z=div⁡(f)𝑍div𝑓Z=\operatorname{div}(f), we have

f​Γ​(DxI,ℒ)=Γ​(DxI,ℒ​(−Z))𝑓Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍f\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})=\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(-Z))

as lattices in Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ)Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}). ∎

5 The local Albanese property

5.1   

If G𝐺G and H𝐻H are two fppf sheaves of abelian groups over S𝑆S, we write Ext¯S1⁡(G,H)superscriptsubscript¯Ext𝑆1𝐺𝐻\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}_{S}^{1}(G,H) for the sheaf over S𝑆S associated to the presheaf

T↦ExtT1⁡(G×ST,H×ST).maps-to𝑇subscriptsuperscriptExt1𝑇subscript𝑆𝐺𝑇subscript𝑆𝐻𝑇T\mapsto\operatorname{Ext}^{1}_{T}(G\times_{S}T,H\times_{S}T).

The next lemma, which seems to be new, is an important input into Theorem 2.3.1.

Lemma 5.1.1.

Let G𝐺G be a commutative affine group scheme over S𝑆S such that 𝒪Gsubscript𝒪𝐺\mathcal{O}_{G} is a projective 𝒪Ssubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{O}_{S}-module. Then the sheaf Ext¯S1⁡(G,𝔾m)subscriptsuperscript¯Ext1𝑆𝐺subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}_{S}(G,\mathbb{G}_{m}) vanishes.

Proof.

We need to show that any extension of fppf sheaves

0⟶𝔾m×T⟶E⟶G×ST⟶0⟶0subscript𝔾𝑚𝑇⟶𝐸⟶subscript𝑆𝐺𝑇⟶00\longrightarrow\mathbb{G}_{m}\times T\longrightarrow E\longrightarrow G\times_{S}T\longrightarrow 0

splits locally on T𝑇T. Since E≅𝔾m×G×ST𝐸subscript𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚𝐺𝑇E\cong\mathbb{G}_{m}\times G\times_{S}T locally on G×STsubscript𝑆𝐺𝑇G\times_{S}T, we see that 𝒪Esubscript𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}_{E} is a projective module over 𝒪G⊗𝒪S𝒪Tsubscripttensor-productsubscript𝒪𝑆subscript𝒪𝐺subscript𝒪𝑇\mathcal{O}_{G}\otimes_{\mathcal{O}_{S}}\mathcal{O}_{T} (recall that projectivity is fppf local). Since 𝒪Gsubscript𝒪𝐺\mathcal{O}_{G} is projective over 𝒪Ssubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{O}_{S}, it follows that 𝒪Esubscript𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}_{E} is a projective 𝒪Tsubscript𝒪𝑇\mathcal{O}_{T}-module.

We now apply Theorem 3.5 in [1] to see that E𝐸E and G𝐺G are 00-reflexive as sheaves of abelian groups over T𝑇T. Hence the 00-dual sequence

0⟶G∗×ST⟶E∗⟶ℤ×T⟶0⟶0subscript𝑆superscript𝐺𝑇⟶superscript𝐸⟶ℤ𝑇⟶00\longrightarrow G^{*}\times_{S}T\longrightarrow E^{*}\longrightarrow\mathbb{Z}\times T\longrightarrow 0

is exact. The fiber of E∗→ℤ×T→superscript𝐸ℤ𝑇E^{*}\to\mathbb{Z}\times T over {1}×T1𝑇\{1\}\times T is therefore a locally trivial torsor on T𝑇T, and a local section of this torsor determines a local splitting of E∗superscript𝐸E^{*}. Dualizing again, we obtain a local splitting of E𝐸E. ∎

Corollary 5.1.1.1.

Any commutative affine group scheme over S𝑆S as in the lemma is 111-reflexive.

Proof.

This follows from the previous lemma combined with Corollary 3.63.63.6 in [7]. ∎

In the factorization setting, we will apply the previous lemma to the arc group.

Lemma 5.1.2.

For any nonempty finite set I𝐼I, the structure sheaf of 𝔏XI+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}\mathbb{G}_{m} is locally projective as an 𝒪XIsubscript𝒪superscript𝑋𝐼\mathcal{O}_{X^{I}}-module.

Proof.

Observe that as a factorization space, the arc group is universal in the sense of [8]. It therefore suffices to treat the case X=𝔸1𝑋superscript𝔸1X=\mathbb{A}^{1}. We proceed by induction on the cardinality of I𝐼I.

For the base case, note that by choosing a global coordinate on X𝑋X, we obtain an isomorphism

𝔏X+​𝔾m⟶𝔏0+​𝔾m×X⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏𝑋subscript𝔾𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝔏0subscript𝔾𝑚𝑋\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{0}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times X

over X𝑋X, where 𝔏0+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏0subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{0}\mathbb{G}_{m} denotes the fiber of 𝔏X+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏𝑋subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X}\mathbb{G}_{m} over 00. Now assume the claim for all finite sets J𝐽J with |J|<|I|𝐽𝐼|J|<|I| and let Δ⊆XIΔsuperscript𝑋𝐼\Delta\subseteq X^{I} denote the main diagonal. Since local projectivity of a sheaf is an fpqc local property, it suffices to check the claim on the cover of XIsuperscript𝑋𝐼X^{I} consisting of the complement of the diagonal and the affinization of the formal completion of XIsuperscript𝑋𝐼X^{I} along ΔΔ\Delta. Note that this cover is indeed fpqc since 𝒪XIsubscript𝒪superscript𝑋𝐼\mathcal{O}_{X^{I}} is Noetherian, and so the natural map from 𝒪XIsubscript𝒪superscript𝑋𝐼\mathcal{O}_{X^{I}} to its completion is flat.

Away from ΔΔ\Delta, we arrive at our desired conclusion using the factorization structure on the arc group and our induction hypothesis. It therefore suffices to check that the structure sheaf of 𝔏XI+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}\mathbb{G}_{m} is locally projective when restricted to the affinization of the formal neighborhood of ΔΔ\Delta. Recall that the counital structure on the arc group provides us, for every injection J→I→𝐽𝐼J\to I, with morphisms

𝔏XI+​𝔾m⟶XI×XJ𝔏XJ+​𝔾m,⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝐽superscript𝑋𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐽subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow X^{I}\times_{X^{J}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{J}}\mathbb{G}_{m},

which are isomorphisms along the formal neighborhood of ΔΔ\Delta. In particular, we may take J𝐽J to be a singleton, reducing to our base case. Hence we see that the structure sheaf of 𝔏XI+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏superscript𝑋𝐼subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{X^{I}}\mathbb{G}_{m} is in fact free when restricted to the affinized completion of XIsuperscript𝑋𝐼X^{I} along ΔΔ\Delta. ∎

5.2   

Consider the Abel-Jacobi map over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}

AJDRan:DRan:subscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ransubscript𝐷Ran\displaystyle\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}:D_{\operatorname{Ran}} ⟶Gr(D)Ran\displaystyle\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}
(xI,y)subscript𝑥𝐼𝑦\displaystyle(x_{I},y) ↦(xI,𝒪X×S​(y),1)maps-toabsentsubscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝒪𝑋𝑆𝑦1\displaystyle\mapsto(x_{I},\mathcal{O}_{X\times S}(y),1)

attached to the multidisk DRansubscript𝐷RanD_{\operatorname{Ran}}. It is an isomorphism onto Gr+1(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}^{1}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}.

Notice that the unital factorization structure on Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} induces a counital factorization structure on its Cartier dual Gr(D)Ran∨\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}} taken over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, compatibly with its commutative group structure.

We now prove the unramified local Cartier duality theorem. Recall the pairing ⟨,]DRan\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} from Proposition 4.7.1.

Theorem 5.2.1.

The pairing ⟨,]DRan\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is perfect. The resulting isomorphism

Gr(D)Ran∨⟶~Pic(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}

is an isomorphism of counital factorization spaces, and agrees with restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}.

Proof.

Let us verify that restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is inverse to the homomorphism

Pic(D)Ran⟶Gr(D)Ran∨\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{\vee}

induced by ⟨,]DRan\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}. Given a section y:S→DxI:𝑦→𝑆subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼y:S\to D_{x_{I}}, we have a tautological isomorphism ⟨ℒ,Γy]DRan≅y∗​ℒsubscriptℒsubscriptΓ𝑦subscript𝐷Ransuperscript𝑦ℒ\langle\mathcal{L},\Gamma_{y}]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}\cong y^{*}\mathcal{L}, which shows that

Pic(D)Ran⟶Gr(D)Ran∨⟶Pic(D)Ran\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}

is isomorphic to the identity.

Conversely, by Proposition 4.6.1 it suffices to show that for any multiplicative line bundle ℳℳ\mathcal{M} on GrxI,+subscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}, a trivialization of ℳ|DxI=AJDxI∗⁡ℳevaluated-atℳsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼superscriptsubscriptAJsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℳ\mathcal{M}|_{D_{x_{I}}}=\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{x_{I}}}^{*}\mathcal{M} determines a trivialization of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. By induction, we may assume that we have constructed a trivialization of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} over GrxI,+dsuperscriptsubscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑑\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}^{d} for all d≤n𝑑𝑛d\leq n.

Observe that the addition morphism

add:DxI×SGrxI,+n⟶GrxI,+n+1:add⟶subscript𝑆subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼superscriptsubscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑛superscriptsubscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑛1\operatorname{add}:D_{x_{I}}\times_{S}\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}^{n}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}^{n+1}

canonically identifies with the universal effective divisor of degree n+1𝑛1n+1, and in particular this morphism is a finite flat covering. The inductive hypothesis yields a trivialization of

add∗⁡ℳ≅ℳ|DxI⊠𝒪Sℳ|GrxI,+n,superscriptaddℳevaluated-atsubscript⊠subscript𝒪𝑆evaluated-atℳsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℳsuperscriptsubscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑛\operatorname{add}^{*}\mathcal{M}\cong\mathcal{M}|_{D_{x_{I}}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{O}_{S}}\mathcal{M}|_{\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}^{n}},

and the cocycle condition on the multiplicative structure of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} ensures that this trivialization descends to GrxI,+n+1superscriptsubscriptGrsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑛1\operatorname{Gr}_{x_{I},+}^{n+1}.

We see by inspection that restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is compatible with counital factorization structures.

It remains to show that Pic(D)Ran\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} is 111-reflexive, from which it will follow that Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} is 111-reflexive. Our argument thus far implies that restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} induces an isomorphism

Gr(D)Ran∗=H−1(Gr(D)Ran∨)⟶~H−1(Pic(D)Ran)=𝔏Ran+𝔾m,\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{*}=H^{-1}(\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{\vee})\tilde{\longrightarrow}H^{-1}(\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}})=\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m},

and that Ext¯Ran1(Gr(D)Ran,𝔾m)=1\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}},\mathbb{G}_{m})=1. By Lemma 5.1.2 and Theorem 3.5 in [1], the arc group 𝔏Ran+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m} is 00-reflexive, and hence

(𝔏Ran+𝔾m)∗⟶~Gr(D)Ran.(\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m})^{*}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}.

Since Pic(D)Ran=BRan𝔏Ran+𝔾m\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}=B_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}, we have

Pic(D)Ran∨=(𝔏Ran+𝔾m)∗.\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{\vee}=(\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m})^{*}.

Dualizing again, we obtain

Pic(D)Ran∨∨=B(𝔏Ran+𝔾m)∗∗,\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{\vee\vee}=B(\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m})^{**},

so we are done by the 00-reflexivity of 𝔏Ran+​𝔾msubscriptsuperscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}. ∎

Corollary 5.2.1.1.

For any 111-reflexive group stack G𝐺G over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} induces an isomorphism

Hom¯Ran(Gr(D)Ran,G)⟶Map¯Ran(DRan,G).\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}},G)\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(D_{\operatorname{Ran}},G).
Proof.

We have

Hom¯Ran(Gr(D)Ran,G)\displaystyle\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}},G) ⟶~Hom¯Ran(G∨,Gr(D)Ran∨)\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}})
⟶~Hom¯Ran(G∨,Pic(D)Ran)\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}})
⟶~​Map¯Ran⁡(DRan,G∨∨)~⟶subscript¯MapRansubscript𝐷Ransuperscript𝐺absent\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(D_{\operatorname{Ran}},G^{\vee\vee})
⟶~​Map¯Ran⁡(DRan,G),~⟶subscript¯MapRansubscript𝐷Ran𝐺\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(D_{\operatorname{Ran}},G),

which is easily seen to agree with restriction along AJDRansubscriptAJsubscript𝐷Ran\operatorname{AJ}_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}. ∎

5.3

The square

Proof.

∎

Lemma 5.3.2.

We have Ext¯Ran1⁡(𝔏Ran​𝔾m,𝔾m)=1subscriptsuperscript¯Ext1Ransubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚subscript𝔾𝑚1\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m},\mathbb{G}_{m})=1.
