5.4   

We are now in a position to prove the local Cartier duality theorem.

Theorem 5.4.1.

The pairing ⟨,]D̊Ran\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is perfect.

Proof.

Consider the diagram

Here the duals are taken over RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, the left and center vertical maps are induced by ⟨,]DRan\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}, and the right vertical map is induced by ⟨,]D̊Ran\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}}. Note that the bottom row is exact by Lemma 5.3.2.

The right square commutes by the construction of ⟨,]DRan\langle\,,\,]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}, and the left square commutes by Proposition 5.3.1. Since the left and center vertical maps are isomorphisms by Theorem 5.2.1, the right vertical map is an isomorphism as desired. ∎

Having established the purely local part of Theorem 2.3.1, we can already deduce the local Albanese property, i.e. Corollary 2.3.1.1. Let G𝐺G be a 111-reflexive commutative group stack relative to RanRan\operatorname{Ran}, meaning G𝐺G is a commutative group prestack over RanRan\operatorname{Ran} such that for any S→Ran→𝑆RanS\to\operatorname{Ran}, the fiber product G×RanSsubscriptRan𝐺𝑆G\times_{\operatorname{Ran}}S is a 111-reflexive commutative group stack over S𝑆S. Then we define the stack of B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-extendable loops

𝔏RanextG:=Hom¯Ran(G∨,Pic(D̊)Ran).\mathfrak{L}^{\operatorname{ext}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}G:=\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}}).

We have a fully faithful embedding

𝔏Ranext​G⟶𝔏Ran​G⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏extRan𝐺subscript𝔏Ran𝐺\mathfrak{L}^{\operatorname{ext}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}G\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}G

whose image can be characterized analogously to what was done in Section 2.2, replacing X𝑋X by D̊̊𝐷\mathring{D} and X¯¯𝑋\overline{X} by D𝐷D.

We now formulate and prove a more precise version of Corollary 2.3.1.1.

Corollary 5.4.1.1.

There is a unique isomorphism

Hom¯Ran⁡(𝔏Ran​𝔾m,G)​⟶~​𝔏Ranext​Gsubscript¯HomRansubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚𝐺~⟶subscriptsuperscript𝔏extRan𝐺\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m},G)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathfrak{L}^{\operatorname{ext}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}G

which is natural in 111-reflexive commutative group stacks G𝐺G relative to RanRan\operatorname{Ran} and specializes to the isomorphism of Theorem 5.4.1 when G=B​𝔾m𝐺𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚G=B\mathbb{G}_{m}. Moreover, this isomorphism is compatible with the factorization structures on both sides.

Proof.

Compose the isomorphisms

Hom¯Ran⁡(𝔏Ran​𝔾m,G)subscript¯HomRansubscript𝔏Ransubscript𝔾𝑚𝐺\displaystyle\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m},G) ⟶~​Hom¯Ran⁡(G∨,𝔏Ran​𝔾m∨)~⟶subscript¯HomRansuperscript𝐺subscript𝔏Ransuperscriptsubscript𝔾𝑚\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(G^{\vee},\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\mathbb{G}_{m}^{\vee})
⟶~Hom¯Ran(G∨,Pic(D̊)Ran)=𝔏RanextG.\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D})_{\operatorname{Ran}})=\mathfrak{L}^{\operatorname{ext}}_{\operatorname{Ran}}G.

The compatibility with factorization structures is manifest. ∎

5.5   

In some cases of interest, the B​𝔾m𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚B\mathbb{G}_{m}-extendability condition is unnecessary. For simplicity we work over a fixed x∈X​(k)𝑥𝑋𝑘x\in X(k) here.

Proposition 5.5.1.

Suppose that G𝐺G is a commutative affine group scheme over k𝑘k. Then we have a canonical isomorphism

𝔏xext​G⟶𝔏x​G.⟶superscriptsubscript𝔏𝑥ext𝐺subscript𝔏𝑥𝐺\mathfrak{L}_{x}^{\operatorname{ext}}G\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{x}G.
Proof.

By Lemma 5.1.1 we have G∨≅B​G∗superscript𝐺𝐵superscript𝐺G^{\vee}\cong BG^{*}. Thus

𝔏xext​G=Hom¯⁡(G∨,Pic⁡(D̊x))≅Hom¯⁡(G∗,𝔏x​𝔾m).superscriptsubscript𝔏𝑥ext𝐺¯Homsuperscript𝐺Picsubscript̊𝐷𝑥¯Homsuperscript𝐺subscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}^{\operatorname{ext}}G=\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G^{\vee},\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x}))\cong\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G^{*},\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m}).

Since G𝐺G is affine its 00-Cartier dual G∗superscript𝐺G^{*} is ind-finite, which implies that

Hom¯⁡(G∗,𝔏x​𝔾m)≅𝔏x​G¯Homsuperscript𝐺subscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚subscript𝔏𝑥𝐺\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(G^{*},\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m})\cong\mathfrak{L}_{x}G

as desired. ∎

Combining the previous proposition with Corollary 2.3.1.1, we obtain the following result.

Corollary 5.5.1.1.

If G𝐺G is as in the proposition, then the isomorphism of Corolllary 5.4.1.1 specializes to

Hom¯⁡(𝔏x​𝔾m,G)​⟶~​𝔏x​G.¯Homsubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚𝐺~⟶subscript𝔏𝑥𝐺\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m},G)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathfrak{L}_{x}G.

6 The unramified global Albanese property

6.1   

For the entirety of this section, we assume that X=X¯𝑋¯𝑋X=\overline{X} is projective.

Definition 6.1.1.

An open subscheme U⊂X×S𝑈𝑋𝑆U\subset X\times S is called a domain relative to S𝑆S if the projection U→S→𝑈𝑆U\to S is surjective.

We define the global affine Grassmannian Gr⁡(X)Gr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}(X) to be the following commutative group stack: a point S→Gr⁡(X)→𝑆Gr𝑋S\to\operatorname{Gr}(X) consists of a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, a domain U⊂X×S𝑈𝑋𝑆U\subset X\times S, and a nonvanishing section of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} over U𝑈U. An isomorphism between two S𝑆S-points of Gr⁡(X)Gr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}(X) is an isomorphism of line bundles under which the two sections agree on a common domain. This is easily seen to be an equivalence relation, i.e. Gr⁡(X)Gr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}(X) is isomorphic to a sheaf of abelian groups.

We will also consider the submonoid Gr+⁡(X)⊂Gr⁡(X)subscriptGr𝑋Gr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(X)\subset\operatorname{Gr}(X) consisting of those points such that the given section extends to X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S (possibly with zeros).

Note that (X×S)∖ΓxI𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼(X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}} is a domain relative to S𝑆S for any xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}. This implies the existence of a canonical map

Gr(D)Ran⟶Gr(X)\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(X) (6.1.1)

which sends Gr+(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} into Gr+⁡(X)subscriptGr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(X).

Proposition 6.1.2.

The map (6.1.1) is an fppf local surjection.

Proof.

A standard argument shows that for any domain U⊂X×S𝑈𝑋𝑆U\subset X\times S, fppf locally on S𝑆S there exists xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} such that (X×S)∖ΓxI⊂U𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼𝑈(X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}}\subset U (see [19], Proposition 2). ∎

Corollary 6.1.2.1.

The inclusion Gr+⁡(X)→Gr⁡(X)→subscriptGr𝑋Gr𝑋\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(X)\to\operatorname{Gr}(X) realizes the latter as the group completion of the former in the category of fppf sheaves.

Proof.

Combine the previous proposition with Proposition 4.6.1. ∎

Let Div+⁡(X)subscriptDiv𝑋\operatorname{Div}_{+}(X) denote the moduli of effective Cartier divisors on X𝑋X, which is a sheaf of commutative monoids. It is well-known that the map

∐d≥0Xdsubscriptcoproduct𝑑0superscript𝑋𝑑\displaystyle\coprod_{d\geq 0}X^{d} ⟶Div+⁡(X)⟶absentsubscriptDiv𝑋\displaystyle\longrightarrow\operatorname{Div}_{+}(X)
(xi)subscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle(x_{i}) ↦∑iximaps-toabsentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\mapsto\sum_{i}x_{i}

factors through an isomorphism

∐d≥0X(d)​⟶~​Div+⁡(X),subscriptcoproduct𝑑0superscript𝑋𝑑~⟶subscriptDiv𝑋\coprod_{d\geq 0}X^{(d)}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Div}_{+}(X),

where X(d):=Xd//ΣdX^{(d)}:=X^{d}/\!/\Sigma_{d} is the dthsuperscript𝑑thd^{\text{th}} symmetric power. Moreover, we have the evident isomorphism

Div+⁡(X)subscriptDiv𝑋\displaystyle\operatorname{Div}_{+}(X) ⟶~​Gr+⁡(X)~⟶subscriptGr𝑋\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Gr}_{+}(X)
Z𝑍\displaystyle Z ↦(𝒪X​(Z),1).maps-toabsentsubscript𝒪𝑋𝑍1\displaystyle\mapsto(\mathcal{O}_{X}(Z),1).

6.2   

Observe that the map AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X} factors through

X𝑋\displaystyle X ⟶Gr⁡(X)⟶absentGr𝑋\displaystyle\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(X) (6.2.1)
x𝑥\displaystyle x ↦(𝒪X​(x),1).maps-toabsentsubscript𝒪𝑋𝑥1\displaystyle\mapsto(\mathcal{O}_{X}(x),1).
Lemma 6.2.1.

Restriction along (6.2.1) induces an isomorphism

Gr(X)∨⟶~Pic(X).\operatorname{Gr}(X)^{\vee}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Pic}(X).

The lemma will be deduced from Theorem 5.2.1 by local-to-global methods. Recall that for any prestack 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, we can consider its de Rham prestack 𝒵dRsubscript𝒵dR\mathcal{Z}_{\operatorname{dR}}, defined by

Map⁡(S,𝒵dR)=Map⁡(Sred,𝒵).Map𝑆subscript𝒵dRMapsubscript𝑆red𝒵\operatorname{Map}(S,\mathcal{Z}_{\operatorname{dR}})=\operatorname{Map}(S_{\operatorname{red}},\mathcal{Z}).

We will also need to consider the space 𝔏Ran+,hor​Ysuperscriptsubscript𝔏Ranhor𝑌\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}Y of horizontal jets into a prestack Y→XdR→𝑌subscript𝑋dRY\to X_{\operatorname{dR}}. See Section 5 of [21], where the construction is called “multijets,” for more details. A point S→𝔏Ran+,hor​Y→𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔏Ranhor𝑌S\to\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}Y consists of xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} together with a map

(ΓxI)dR×SdRS⟶Y⟶subscriptsubscript𝑆dRsubscriptsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼dR𝑆𝑌(\Gamma_{x_{I}})_{\operatorname{dR}}\times_{S_{\operatorname{dR}}}S\longrightarrow Y

over XdRsubscript𝑋dRX_{\operatorname{dR}}. It is not difficult to see that 𝔏Ran+,hor​Ysuperscriptsubscript𝔏Ranhor𝑌\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}Y has a natural structure of counital factorization space, and moreover we have

𝔏X+,hor​Y=Y×XdRX.superscriptsubscript𝔏𝑋hor𝑌subscriptsubscript𝑋dR𝑌𝑋\mathfrak{L}_{X}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}Y=Y\times_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}}X.

Restriction along the map

DxI⟶(DxI)dR×SdRS=(ΓxI)dR×SdRS⟶subscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼subscriptsubscript𝑆dRsubscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼dR𝑆subscriptsubscript𝑆dRsubscriptsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼dR𝑆D_{x_{I}}\longrightarrow(D_{x_{I}})_{\operatorname{dR}}\times_{S_{\operatorname{dR}}}S=(\Gamma_{x_{I}})_{\operatorname{dR}}\times_{S_{\operatorname{dR}}}S

defines a morphism of counital factorization spaces

𝔏Ran+,hor​Y⟶𝔏Ran+​(Y×XdRX).⟶superscriptsubscript𝔏Ranhor𝑌superscriptsubscript𝔏Ransubscriptsubscript𝑋dR𝑌𝑋\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}Y\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+}(Y\times_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}}X).
Proof of Lemma 6.2.1.

Let Pic(D)XdR\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}} denote the space over XdRsubscript𝑋dRX_{\operatorname{dR}} defined as follows: a point S→Pic(D)XdRS\to\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}} consists of x:Sred→X:𝑥→subscript𝑆red𝑋x:S_{\operatorname{red}}\to X together with a line bundle on Dxsubscript𝐷𝑥D_{x} (note that the completion along ΓxsubscriptΓ𝑥\Gamma_{x} is well-defined even though x𝑥x is only defined on Sredsubscript𝑆redS_{\operatorname{red}}). Clearly we have

Pic(D)X=Pic(D)Xd​R×XdRX.\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X}=\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X_{dR}}\times_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}}X.

Tracing through the definitions, we have a tautological isomorphism of counital factorization spaces

Pic(D)Ran⟶~𝔏Ran+,hor(Pic(D)XdR).\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathfrak{L}_{\operatorname{Ran}}^{+,\operatorname{hor}}(\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}}).

Consider the moduli stack of sections of the projection Pic(D)Ran→Ran\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\to\operatorname{Ran} compatible with the counital factorization structure. By Theorem 5.2.3 in [21], this stack of factorizable sections identifies with the stack of sections of Pic(D)XdR→XdR\operatorname{Pic}(D)_{X_{\operatorname{dR}}}\to X_{\operatorname{dR}}. The latter is tautologically isomorphic to Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X).

We claim that the map Gr(D)Ran→Gr(X)\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\to\operatorname{Gr}(X) induces an isomorphism from Gr(X)∨\operatorname{Gr}(X)^{\vee} to the moduli stack of sections of Gr(D)Ran∨→Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}}\to\operatorname{Ran} compatible with the counital factorization structure. Then the lemma will follow from Theorem 5.2.1 by commutativity of the square

It follows from Proposition 5.2.2 of [2] that the canonical map

|Ran∙×Gr(D)Ran|⟶Gr(X)|\operatorname{Ran}^{\bullet}\times\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}|\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(X)

is an isomorphism locally in the fppf topology, where the left side denotes the geometric realization of the simplicial prestack determined by the action of RanRan\operatorname{Ran} on Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}} coming from the unital structure. One checks from the definitions that multiplicative line bundles on this geometric realization are precisely counital factorizable sections of Gr(D)Ran∨\operatorname{Gr}(D)^{\vee}_{\operatorname{Ran}}, as desired. ∎

6.3   

A standard argument shows that any family of line bundles on X𝑋X trivializes over a domain, i.e. the projection Gr⁡(X)→Pic⁡(X)→Gr𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Gr}(X)\to\operatorname{Pic}(X) is an fppf local surjection. Thus we have an exact triangle of commutative group stacks

Rat⁡(X)⟶Gr⁡(X)⟶Pic⁡(X).⟶Rat𝑋Gr𝑋⟶Pic𝑋\operatorname{Rat}(X)\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr}(X)\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X).

Here RatRat\operatorname{Rat} is the moduli of invertible rational functions on X𝑋X.

We will need the following lemma.

Lemma 6.3.1.

Let V𝑉V be a finite-dimensional vector space and U⊂ℙ​(V)𝑈ℙ𝑉U\subset\mathbb{P}(V) an open subscheme whose complement has codimension at least 333. Then the restriction map

Map¯⁡(ℙ​(V),B​𝔾m)⟶Map¯⁡(U,B​𝔾m)⟶¯Mapℙ𝑉𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚¯Map𝑈𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathbb{P}(V),B\mathbb{G}_{m})\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(U,B\mathbb{G}_{m})

is an isomorphism.

Proof.

Fix a test scheme S𝑆S. Extending scalars if necessary, we may assume that U𝑈U has a rational point p∈U​(k)𝑝𝑈𝑘p\in U(k). Denote by C𝐶C the projective cone on ℙ​(V)∖Uℙ𝑉𝑈\mathbb{P}(V)\setminus U with vertex p𝑝p, and put U0:=ℙ​(V)∖Cassignsubscript𝑈0ℙ𝑉𝐶U_{0}:=\mathbb{P}(V)\setminus C. Since C𝐶C has codimension at least 222, functions on U0×Ssubscript𝑈0𝑆U_{0}\times S extend to ℙ​(V)×Sℙ𝑉𝑆\mathbb{P}(V)\times S, so the restriction functors

Map⁡(ℙ​(V)×S,B​𝔾m)⟶Map⁡(U×S,B​𝔾m)⟶Map⁡(U0×S,B​𝔾m)⟶Mapℙ𝑉𝑆𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚Map𝑈𝑆𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚⟶Mapsubscript𝑈0𝑆𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{Map}(\mathbb{P}(V)\times S,B\mathbb{G}_{m})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Map}(U\times S,B\mathbb{G}_{m})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Map}(U_{0}\times S,B\mathbb{G}_{m})

are fully faithful. Therefore it suffices to show that for any line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on U×S𝑈𝑆U\times S, the restriction ℒ|U0×Sevaluated-atℒsubscript𝑈0𝑆\mathcal{L}|_{U_{0}\times S} extends to ℙ​(V)×Sℙ𝑉𝑆\mathbb{P}(V)\times S.

Let E⊂U×U0𝐸𝑈subscript𝑈0E\subset U\times U_{0} be the subscheme of pairs (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) such that x𝑥x, y𝑦y, and p𝑝p are collinear. Write π:E→U:𝜋→𝐸𝑈\pi:E\to U and ρ:E→U0:𝜌→𝐸subscript𝑈0\rho:E\to U_{0} for the projections. Since ρ𝜌\rho is a ℙ1superscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}^{1}-bundle, the degree of (π×idS)∗​ℒsuperscript𝜋subscriptid𝑆ℒ(\pi\times\operatorname{id}_{S})^{*}\mathcal{L} is a locally constant function on U0×Ssubscript𝑈0𝑆U_{0}\times S. Thus, by twisting ℒℒ\mathcal{L} appropriately we can assume that (π×idS)∗​ℒ≅(ρ×idS)∗​ℒ′superscript𝜋subscriptid𝑆ℒsuperscript𝜌subscriptid𝑆superscriptℒ′(\pi\times\operatorname{id}_{S})^{*}\mathcal{L}\cong(\rho\times\operatorname{id}_{S})^{*}\mathcal{L}^{\prime} for some line bundle ℒ′superscriptℒ′\mathcal{L}^{\prime} on U0×Ssubscript𝑈0𝑆U_{0}\times S, and we are trying to prove that ℒ|U0×Sevaluated-atℒsubscript𝑈0𝑆\mathcal{L}|_{U_{0}\times S} is pulled back from S𝑆S.

Restricting the chosen isomorphism along ΔU0×idSsubscriptΔsubscript𝑈0subscriptid𝑆\Delta_{U_{0}}\times\operatorname{id}_{S}, we obtain ℒ|U0×S≅ℒ′evaluated-atℒsubscript𝑈0𝑆superscriptℒ′\mathcal{L}|_{U_{0}\times S}\cong\mathcal{L}^{\prime}. On the other hand, we can restrict the same isomorphism along the section p×idU0×idS𝑝subscriptidsubscript𝑈0subscriptid𝑆p\times\operatorname{id}_{U_{0}}\times\operatorname{id}_{S} of ρ×idS𝜌subscriptid𝑆\rho\times\operatorname{id}_{S}, which yields an identification ℒ|U0×S≅𝒪U0⊠(ℒ|p×idS)evaluated-atℒsubscript𝑈0𝑆⊠subscript𝒪subscript𝑈0evaluated-atℒ𝑝subscriptid𝑆\mathcal{L}|_{U_{0}\times S}\cong\mathcal{O}_{U_{0}}\boxtimes(\mathcal{L}|_{p\times\operatorname{id}_{S}}) as needed. ∎

6.4   

Let K𝐾K denote the k𝑘k-vector space of rational functions on X𝑋X. We present K𝐾K as an ind-scheme using the formula

colim𝑍​Γ​(X,𝒪X​(Z))=K𝑍colimΓ𝑋subscript𝒪𝑋𝑍𝐾\underset{Z}{\operatorname{colim}}\ \Gamma(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(Z))=K

where Z𝑍Z runs through all effective divisors on X𝑋X.

Observe that the ind-scheme K×:=K∖{0}assignsuperscript𝐾𝐾0K^{\times}:=K\setminus\{0\} is a commutative monoid under multiplication, although not a group. There is an injective monoid homomorphism K×→Rat→superscript𝐾RatK^{\times}\to\operatorname{Rat}, which can be seen as follows. A morphism S→K×→𝑆superscript𝐾S\to K^{\times} lands in some Γ​(X,𝒪​(Z))∖{0}Γ𝑋𝒪𝑍0\Gamma(X,\mathcal{O}(Z))\setminus\{0\}, hence determines a function f:(X∖Z)×S→𝔸1:𝑓→𝑋𝑍𝑆superscript𝔸1f:(X\setminus Z)\times S\to\mathbb{A}^{1} which does not vanish identically on any fiber over a point of S𝑆S. This means that the complement of the vanishing locus of f𝑓f is a domain.

Lemma 6.4.1.

The inclusion K×→Rat⁡(X)→superscript𝐾Rat𝑋K^{\times}\to\operatorname{Rat}(X) realizes the latter as the group completion as the former in the category of Zariski sheaves.

Proof.

The group completion of K×superscript𝐾K^{\times} injects into RatRat\operatorname{Rat} because the multiplication in K×superscript𝐾K^{\times} is cancellative. Thus it remains to prove surjectivity.

Fix a domain U⊂X×S𝑈𝑋𝑆U\subset X\times S and f:U→𝔾m:𝑓→𝑈subscript𝔾𝑚f:U\to\mathbb{G}_{m}. Choose a closed point x𝑥x in X𝑋X and put X̊:=X∖{x}assign̊𝑋𝑋𝑥\mathring{X}:=X\setminus\{x\}. Shrink U𝑈U if necessary so that U⊂X̊×S𝑈̊𝑋𝑆U\subset\mathring{X}\times S, and fix a closed point s𝑠s in S𝑆S. Then there is a function g𝑔g on X̊×S̊𝑋𝑆\mathring{X}\times S which vanishes on the complement of U𝑈U but does not vanish identically on the fiber X̊ssubscript̊𝑋𝑠\mathring{X}_{s}. Replacing S𝑆S by a Zariski neighborhood of s𝑠s, we may assume g𝑔g does not vanish identically on any fiber over a point of S𝑆S. Now there exists m𝑚m so that f​gm𝑓superscript𝑔𝑚fg^{m} is regular on X̊×S̊𝑋𝑆\mathring{X}\times S, which means for sufficiently large n𝑛n we have

f​gm∈Γ​(X×S,𝒪​(n​x)⊠𝒪S)𝑓superscript𝑔𝑚Γ𝑋𝑆⊠𝒪𝑛𝑥subscript𝒪𝑆fg^{m}\in\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{O}(nx)\boxtimes\mathcal{O}_{S})

and likewise for gmsuperscript𝑔𝑚g^{m}. Thus f𝑓f can be written as the ratio of two S𝑆S-points of Γ​(X,𝒪​(n​x))∖{0}⊂K×Γ𝑋𝒪𝑛𝑥0superscript𝐾\Gamma(X,\mathcal{O}(nx))\setminus\{0\}\subset K^{\times}.

∎

The previous lemma implies that K××K×→Rat⁡(X)→superscript𝐾superscript𝐾Rat𝑋K^{\times}\times K^{\times}\to\operatorname{Rat}(X) given by (f,g)↦f/gmaps-to𝑓𝑔𝑓𝑔(f,g)\mapsto f/g is a Zariski epimorphism. Moreover, this map is evidently 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m}-equivariant with respect to the diagonal action on K××K×superscript𝐾superscript𝐾K^{\times}\times K^{\times} and the trivial action on Rat⁡(X)Rat𝑋\operatorname{Rat}(X), so we obtain

(K××K×)/𝔾m⟶Rat⁡(X).⟶superscript𝐾superscript𝐾subscript𝔾𝑚Rat𝑋(K^{\times}\times K^{\times})/\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Rat}(X). (6.4.1)

Observe that the domain is the ind-projective space ℙ​(K⊕K)ℙdirect-sum𝐾𝐾\mathbb{P}(K\oplus K) with the subspaces ℙ​(K⊕0)ℙdirect-sum𝐾0\mathbb{P}(K\oplus 0) and ℙ​(0⊕K)ℙdirect-sum0𝐾\mathbb{P}(0\oplus K) removed. Moreover, the fiber over 1∈Rat⁡(X)1Rat𝑋1\in\operatorname{Rat}(X) is the diagonally embedded ℙ​(K)ℙ𝐾\mathbb{P}(K). Note that (6.4.1) is a monoid homomorphism, so (6.4.1) is a bundle with fiber ℙ​(K)ℙ𝐾\mathbb{P}(K).

Lemma 6.4.2.

We have Rat(X)∨=1\operatorname{Rat}(X)^{\vee}=1.

Proof.

Suppose we are given a function (K××K×)/𝔾m×S→𝔸1→superscript𝐾superscript𝐾subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆superscript𝔸1(K^{\times}\times K^{\times})/\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S\to\mathbb{A}^{1}. We claim it extends to ℙ​(K⊕K)×Sℙdirect-sum𝐾𝐾𝑆\mathbb{P}(K\oplus K)\times S, which will imply it is pulled back from S𝑆S. Since (6.4.1) is a Zariski epimorphism, it will follow that any function on Rat⁡(X)×SRat𝑋𝑆\operatorname{Rat}(X)\times S is pulled back from S𝑆S, and hence Hom¯​(Rat⁡(X),𝔾m)=1¯HomRat𝑋subscript𝔾𝑚1\underline{\operatorname{Hom}}(\operatorname{Rat}(X),\mathbb{G}_{m})=1. Namely, if V⊂K𝑉𝐾V\subset K is a finite-dimensional subspace with dimV>1dimension𝑉1\dim V>1, then we obtain a function on the complement in ℙ​(V⊕V)×Sℙdirect-sum𝑉𝑉𝑆\mathbb{P}(V\oplus V)\times S of (ℙ​(V⊕{0})∪ℙ​({0}⊕V))×Sℙdirect-sum𝑉0ℙdirect-sum0𝑉𝑆(\mathbb{P}(V\oplus\{0\})\cup\mathbb{P}(\{0\}\oplus V))\times S. Since ℙ​(V⊕{0})ℙdirect-sum𝑉0\mathbb{P}(V\oplus\{0\}) and ℙ({0}⊕V))\mathbb{P}(\{0\}\oplus V)) are subspaces of codimension at least two, the function extends to ℙ​(V⊕V)×Sℙdirect-sum𝑉𝑉𝑆\mathbb{P}(V\oplus V)\times S as desired.

Given a multiplicative line bundle on Rat⁡(X)×SRat𝑋𝑆\operatorname{Rat}(X)\times S, pull back along the map (6.4.1) to obtain a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on (K××K×)/𝔾m×Ssuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆(K^{\times}\times K^{\times})/\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S. It is enough to show that ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is pulled back from S𝑆S, because (6.4.1) is an ind-projective bundle and hence inverse image of line bundles is fully faithful. Lemma 6.3.1 implies that ℒℒ\mathcal{L} extends to ℙ​(K⊕K)×Sℙdirect-sum𝐾𝐾𝑆\mathbb{P}(K\oplus K)\times S. Thus, in order to prove that ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is pulled back from S𝑆S, we need only show that its degree is zero. For this, note that ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is trivial when restricted to the diagonal ℙ​(K)ℙ𝐾\mathbb{P}(K), the latter being the kernel of (6.4.1). ∎

6.5   

Finally, we complete the proof of the main result in the unramified case.

Proof of Theorem 2.2.1 for X=X¯𝑋¯𝑋X=\overline{X}.

The Abel-Jacobi map factors as X→Gr⁡(X)→Pic⁡(X)→𝑋Gr𝑋→Pic𝑋X\to\operatorname{Gr}(X)\to\operatorname{Pic}(X). By Lemma 6.2.1, restriction along X→Gr⁡(X)→𝑋Gr𝑋X\to\operatorname{Gr}(X) induces an isomorphism Gr(X)∨→~Pic(X)\operatorname{Gr}(X)^{\vee}\tilde{\to}\operatorname{Pic}(X). Lemma 6.4.2 then implies that Pic(X)∨→Gr(X)∨\operatorname{Pic}(X)^{\vee}\to\operatorname{Gr}(X)^{\vee} is an isomorphism. ∎

In particular, we obtain a perfect pairing

⟨,⟩X:Pic(X)×Pic(X)⟶B𝔾m.\langle\,,\,\rangle_{X}:\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X)\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}.

We also record for later use the following result, which can be interpreted as the unramified case of the local-global compatibility in Theorem 2.3.1.

Proposition 6.5.1.

Let I𝐼I denote a finite set of closed points in X𝑋X. Then the square

commutes up to canonical natural isomorphism.

Proof.

This amounts to an isomorphism

⟨ℒ,𝒪X​(Z)⟩X​⟶~​⨂x∈I⟨ℒ|Dx,Zx]Dxsubscriptℒsubscript𝒪𝑋𝑍𝑋~⟶subscripttensor-product𝑥𝐼subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷𝑥subscript𝑍𝑥subscript𝐷𝑥\langle\mathcal{L},\mathcal{O}_{X}(Z)\rangle_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\bigotimes_{x\in I}\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x}},Z_{x}]_{D_{x}}

for any line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S and any divisor Z=∑x∈IZx𝑍subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝑍𝑥Z=\sum_{x\in I}Z_{x} where Zxsubscript𝑍𝑥Z_{x} is supported in Dx×Ssubscript𝐷𝑥𝑆D_{x}\times S. By Theorem 5.2.1 it suffices to treat the case Z=Γy𝑍subscriptΓ𝑦Z=\Gamma_{y} where y:S→Dx:𝑦→𝑆subscript𝐷𝑥y:S\to D_{x} for some x∈I𝑥𝐼x\in I. But then we have

⟨ℒ,𝒪X​(Γy)⟩X​⟶~​y∗​ℒ​⟶~​⟨ℒ|Dx,Γy]Dx.subscriptℒsubscript𝒪𝑋subscriptΓ𝑦𝑋~⟶superscript𝑦ℒ~⟶subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷𝑥subscriptΓ𝑦subscript𝐷𝑥\langle\mathcal{L},\mathcal{O}_{X}(\Gamma_{y})\rangle_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}y^{*}\mathcal{L}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x}},\Gamma_{y}]_{D_{x}}.

∎

7 The ramified global Albanese property

7.1   

In what follows, let I𝐼I denote the (finite) set of points in X¯∖X¯𝑋𝑋\overline{X}\setminus X. We begin with the following general lemma.

Lemma 7.1.1.

Let G𝐺G be a commutative group stack. Let A𝐴A be a 00-reflexive sheaf of abelian groups with Ext¯1⁡(A,𝔾m)=Ext¯1⁡(A∗,𝔾m)=1superscript¯Ext1𝐴subscript𝔾𝑚superscript¯Ext1superscript𝐴subscript𝔾𝑚1\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}(A,\mathbb{G}_{m})=\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}(A^{*},\mathbb{G}_{m})=1. If there exists an exact triangle

A⟶H⟶G⟶𝐴𝐻⟶𝐺A\longrightarrow H\longrightarrow G

where H𝐻H is 111-reflexive, then G𝐺G is 111-reflexive.

Proof.

Since A𝐴A is 00-reflexive and Ext¯1⁡(A,𝔾m)=1superscript¯Ext1𝐴subscript𝔾𝑚1\operatorname{\underline{Ext}}^{1}(A,\mathbb{G}_{m})=1, we have that A𝐴A is 111-reflexive with A∨≃B​A∗similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝐴𝐵superscript𝐴A^{\vee}\simeq BA^{*}. From the fact that H0​(B​A∗)=1superscript𝐻0𝐵superscript𝐴1H^{0}(BA^{*})=1, it follows that the dual sequence

G∨⟶H∨⟶B​A∗⟶superscript𝐺superscript𝐻⟶𝐵superscript𝐴G^{\vee}\longrightarrow H^{\vee}\longrightarrow BA^{*}

is exact (Proposition 3.18 in [7]), hence so is the rotated triangle

A∗⟶G∨⟶H∨.⟶superscript𝐴superscript𝐺⟶superscript𝐻A^{*}\longrightarrow G^{\vee}\longrightarrow H^{\vee}.

Apply the same argument again to obtain the exact triangle

A∗∗⟶H∨∨⟶G∨∨.⟶superscript𝐴absentsuperscript𝐻absent⟶superscript𝐺absentA^{**}\longrightarrow H^{\vee\vee}\longrightarrow G^{\vee\vee}.

Clearly the diagram

commutes, so the 111-reflexivity of G𝐺G follows from the hypotheses that A𝐴A is 00-reflexive and H𝐻H is 111-reflexive. ∎

7.2   

We may now prove Theorem 2.2.1 for an open curve.

Proof of Theorem 2.2.1.

First, note that Lemma 7.1.1 applied to the exact triangle

∏x∈IGr⁡(Dx)⟶Pic⁡(X¯)⟶Pic⁡(X)⟶subscriptproduct𝑥𝐼Grsubscript𝐷𝑥Pic¯𝑋⟶Pic𝑋\prod_{x\in I}\operatorname{Gr}(D_{x})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(\overline{X})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X) (7.2.1)

implies that Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) is 111-reflexive. The hypotheses of the lemma are satisfied for Gr⁡(Dx)Grsubscript𝐷𝑥\operatorname{Gr}(D_{x}) by Theorem 5.2.1.

Consider the square

which commutes by Proposition 6.5.1. Recall that the vertical arrows are isomorphisms by Proposition 5.2.1 and the X=X¯𝑋¯𝑋X=\overline{X} case of Theorem 2.2.1. Passing to the fibers of the horizontal morphisms, we obtain an isomorphism

Pic(X,∂X)⟶~Pic(X)∨.\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Pic}(X)^{\vee}. (7.2.2)

In particular, we see that Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X) is also 111-reflexive.

It remains only to show that the isomorphism

Pic(X,∂X)∨⟶~Pic(X)\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)^{\vee}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Pic}(X)

dual to (7.2.2) agrees with restriction along AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X}. This amounts to commutativity of the triangle

where the diagonal arrow is the tautological map y↦(ℒ↦y∗​ℒ)maps-to𝑦maps-toℒsuperscript𝑦ℒy\mapsto(\mathcal{L}\mapsto y^{*}\mathcal{L}). Denoting by

⟨,]X:Pic(X)×Pic(X,∂X)⟶B𝔾m\langle\,,\,]_{X}:\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}

the pairing corresponding to (7.2.2), we must exhibit a natural isomorphism

⟨(𝒪X¯​(y),1),ℒ]X​⟶~​y∗​ℒsubscriptsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦1ℒ𝑋~⟶superscript𝑦ℒ\langle(\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y),1),\mathcal{L}]_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}y^{*}\mathcal{L}

for any y:S→X:𝑦→𝑆𝑋y:S\to X and any extendable line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S.

First, for ℒ=ℒ¯|Xℒevaluated-at¯ℒ𝑋\mathcal{L}=\overline{\mathcal{L}}|_{X} where ℒ¯¯ℒ\overline{\mathcal{L}} is a line bundle on X¯×S¯𝑋𝑆\overline{X}\times S, we have

⟨(𝒪X¯​(y),1),ℒ¯|X]X=⟨𝒪X¯​(y),ℒ¯⟩X¯​⟶~​y∗​ℒ¯=y∗​ℒ.subscriptsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦1evaluated-at¯ℒ𝑋𝑋subscriptsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦¯ℒ¯𝑋~⟶superscript𝑦¯ℒsuperscript𝑦ℒ\langle(\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y),1),\overline{\mathcal{L}}|_{X}]_{X}=\langle\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y),\overline{\mathcal{L}}\rangle_{\overline{X}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}y^{*}\overline{\mathcal{L}}=y^{*}\mathcal{L}.

In view of the exact triangle (7.2.1), it remains to show that in the case ℒ¯=𝒪X¯​(Z)¯ℒsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑍\overline{\mathcal{L}}=\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(Z) where Z=∑x∈IZx𝑍subscript𝑥𝐼subscript𝑍𝑥Z=\sum_{x\in I}Z_{x} with Zxsubscript𝑍𝑥Z_{x} supported on ⊔x∈IDx×Ssubscriptsquare-union𝑥𝐼subscript𝐷𝑥𝑆\sqcup_{x\in I}D_{x}\times S, the resulting trivializations of both sides of

⟨𝒪X¯​(y),ℒ¯⟩X¯​⟶~​y∗​ℒsubscriptsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦¯ℒ¯𝑋~⟶superscript𝑦ℒ\langle\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y),\overline{\mathcal{L}}\rangle_{\overline{X}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}y^{*}\mathcal{L}

match up. Here the left side is trivialized via

⟨𝒪X¯​(y),𝒪X¯​(Z)⟩X¯​⟶~​⨂x∈I⟨𝒪X¯​(y)|Dx,Zx]Dx​⟶~​⨂x∈I⟨𝒪Dx,Zx]Dx​⟶~​𝒪S.subscriptsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦subscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑍¯𝑋~⟶subscripttensor-product𝑥𝐼subscriptevaluated-atsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑦subscript𝐷𝑥subscript𝑍𝑥subscript𝐷𝑥~⟶subscripttensor-product𝑥𝐼subscriptsubscript𝒪subscript𝐷𝑥subscript𝑍𝑥subscript𝐷𝑥~⟶subscript𝒪𝑆\langle\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y),\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(Z)\rangle_{\overline{X}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\bigotimes_{x\in I}\langle\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(y)|_{D_{x}},Z_{x}]_{D_{x}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\bigotimes_{x\in I}\langle\mathcal{O}_{D_{x}},Z_{x}]_{D_{x}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathcal{O}_{S}.

One verifies by a diagram chase that this coincides with the trivialization obtained by restricting 1:𝒪X¯→𝒪X¯​(Z):1→subscript𝒪¯𝑋subscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑍1:\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}\to\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(Z) along y𝑦y.

∎

Proof of Corollary 2.2.1.1.

The proof is identical to that of Corollary 2.3.1.1, replacing 𝔏x​𝔾msubscript𝔏𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}_{x}\mathbb{G}_{m} by Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X) and Pic⁡(D̊x)Picsubscript̊𝐷𝑥\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x}) by Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X). ∎

7.3   

We now complete the proof of Theorem 2.3.1 by establishing local-global compatibility.

Proof of Theorem 2.3.1.

The nondegeneracy of ⟨,]D̊Ran\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}} is Theorem 5.4.1, and compatibility with factorization structures is clear from the construction of the pairing. Thus it remains only to prove the commutativity of the diagram (2.3.2). Commutativity of the right square amounts to commutativity of the square

This is proved similarly to Proposition 5.3.1: by Theorem 2.2.1 it suffices to show the two compositions agree when restricted along AJX×AJXsubscriptAJ𝑋subscriptAJ𝑋\operatorname{AJ}_{X}\times\operatorname{AJ}_{X}, and indeed both restrictions identify with 𝒪X×X​(Δ)subscript𝒪𝑋𝑋Δ\mathcal{O}_{X\times X}(\Delta).

Finally, we establish commutativity of the left square in (2.3.2), or equivalently commutativity of the square

Recall that we have an exact triangle

∏x∈IGr⁡(Dx)⟶Pic⁡(X¯)⟶Pic⁡(X),⟶subscriptproduct𝑥𝐼Grsubscript𝐷𝑥Pic¯𝑋⟶Pic𝑋\prod_{x\in I}\operatorname{Gr}(D_{x})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(\overline{X})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X),

and hence an exact triangle

Pic(X)∨⟶Pic(X¯)∨⟶∏x∈IGr(Dx)∨\operatorname{Pic}(X)^{\vee}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(\overline{X})^{\vee}\longrightarrow\prod_{x\in I}\operatorname{Gr}(D_{x})^{\vee}

because Ext¯1​(Gr⁡(Dx),𝔾m)=1superscript¯Ext1Grsubscript𝐷𝑥subscript𝔾𝑚1\underline{\operatorname{Ext}}^{1}(\operatorname{Gr}(D_{x}),\mathbb{G}_{m})=1 by Theorem 5.2.1. Thus it suffices to construct an isomorphism of line bundles

⟨ℒ|X,(𝒪X,f)]X​⟶~​⨂x∈I⟨ℒ|D̊x,fx]D̊xsubscriptevaluated-atℒ𝑋subscript𝒪𝑋𝑓𝑋~⟶subscripttensor-product𝑥𝐼subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝑓𝑥subscript̊𝐷𝑥\langle\mathcal{L}|_{X},(\mathcal{O}_{X},f)]_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\bigotimes_{x\in I}\langle\mathcal{L}|_{\mathring{D}_{x}},f_{x}]_{\mathring{D}_{x}} (7.3.1)

for any line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X¯×S¯𝑋𝑆\overline{X}\times S and any f=(fx)x∈I𝑓subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑥𝑥𝐼f=(f_{x})_{x\in I} where fx:D̊x,S→𝔾m:subscript𝑓𝑥→subscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚f_{x}:\mathring{D}_{x,S}\to\mathbb{G}_{m}, such that for ℒ=𝒪X¯​(Z)ℒsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑍\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(Z) with Z𝑍Z a divisor supported on ⊔x∈IDx×Ssubscriptsquare-union𝑥𝐼subscript𝐷𝑥𝑆\sqcup_{x\in I}D_{x}\times S, the resulting trivializations of both sides match up under (7.3.1).

Indeed, we have

⟨ℒ|X,(𝒪X,f)]Xsubscriptevaluated-atℒ𝑋subscript𝒪𝑋𝑓𝑋\displaystyle\langle\mathcal{L}|_{X},(\mathcal{O}_{X},f)]_{X} ⟶~​⟨ℒ,𝒪X¯​(div⁡(f))⟩X¯~⟶subscriptℒsubscript𝒪¯𝑋div𝑓¯𝑋\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\langle\mathcal{L},\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(\operatorname{div}(f))\rangle_{\overline{X}}
⟶~​⨂x∈I⟨ℒ|Dx,div⁡(fx)]Dx~⟶subscripttensor-product𝑥𝐼subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷𝑥divsubscript𝑓𝑥subscript𝐷𝑥\displaystyle\tilde{\longrightarrow}\bigotimes_{x\in I}\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x}},\operatorname{div}(f_{x})]_{D_{x}}

Here the first isomorphism was established in the proof of Theorem 2.2.1, the second isomorphism is Proposition 6.5.1, and the last isomorphism is by the definition of ⟨,]Dx\langle\,,\,]_{D_{x}}.

For ℒ=𝒪X¯​(Z)ℒsubscript𝒪¯𝑋𝑍\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X}}(Z), one traces through the constructions to see that the resulting trivializations

⟨ℒ|X,(𝒪X,f)]X​⟶~​⟨𝒪X,(𝒪X,f)]X​⟶~​𝒪Ssubscriptevaluated-atℒ𝑋subscript𝒪𝑋𝑓𝑋~⟶subscriptsubscript𝒪𝑋subscript𝒪𝑋𝑓𝑋~⟶subscript𝒪𝑆\langle\mathcal{L}|_{X},(\mathcal{O}_{X},f)]_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\langle\mathcal{O}_{X},(\mathcal{O}_{X},f)]_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathcal{O}_{S}

and

⟨ℒ|D̊x,fx]D̊x​⟶~​⟨𝒪D̊x,fx]D̊x​⟶~​𝒪Ssubscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝑓𝑥subscript̊𝐷𝑥~⟶subscriptsubscript𝒪subscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝑓𝑥subscript̊𝐷𝑥~⟶subscript𝒪𝑆\langle\mathcal{L}|_{\mathring{D}_{x}},f_{x}]_{\mathring{D}_{x}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\langle\mathcal{O}_{\mathring{D}_{x}},f_{x}]_{\mathring{D}_{x}}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\mathcal{O}_{S}

match up under (7.3.1). ∎

8 Global determinant formulas

8.1   

The goal of this section is to give a formula for the global pairing

⟨,]X:Pic(X)×Pic(X,∂X)⟶B𝔾m\langle\,,\,]_{X}:\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\longrightarrow B\mathbb{G}_{m}

in terms of determinants, analogously to how the local pairing ⟨,]D̊Ran\langle\,,\,]_{\mathring{D}_{\operatorname{Ran}}} was defined.

First we treat the case where X=X¯𝑋¯𝑋X=\overline{X} is projective. We will need the following lemma. Fix xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I} and a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S.

Lemma 8.1.1.

Restriction from X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S to D̊xIsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼\mathring{D}_{x_{I}} realizes Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ)Γ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}) as a colattice in the Tate vector bundle Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ)Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}) on S𝑆S.

Proof.

Twisting by a divisor supported on ΓxIsubscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼\Gamma_{x_{I}}, we may assume that ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is of arbitrarily large degree, and hence that R1​Γ​(X×S,ℒ)=0superscript𝑅1Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ0R^{1}\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L})=0. Thus R0​Γ​(X×S,ℒ)superscript𝑅0Γ𝑋𝑆ℒR^{0}\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}) is a vector bundle on S𝑆S, and we have a short exact sequence

0⟶R0​Γ​(X×S,ℒ)⟶Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ)⊕Γ​(DxI,ℒ)⟶Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ)⟶0.⟶0superscript𝑅0Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ⟶direct-sumΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ⟶Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ⟶00\longrightarrow R^{0}\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L})\longrightarrow\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})\oplus\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})\longrightarrow\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})\longrightarrow 0.

Since Γ​(DxI,ℒ)Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}) is linearly compact and open in Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ)Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}), the claim follows. ∎

Continuing to assume that X=X¯𝑋¯𝑋X=\overline{X}, for any line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S we obtain a perfect complex R​Γ​(X×S,ℒ)𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒR\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}) on S𝑆S, which has a well-defined determinant line.

Theorem 8.1.2.

For any line bundles ℒℒ\mathcal{L} and ℳℳ\mathcal{M} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, the line bundle ⟨ℒ,ℳ⟩Xsubscriptℒℳ𝑋\langle\mathcal{L},\mathcal{M}\rangle_{X} on S𝑆S is naturally isomorphic to

detR​Γ​(X×S,ℒ⊗ℳ)⊗(detR​Γ​(X×S,ℒ))−1⊗(detR​Γ​(X×S,ℳ))−1⊗detR​Γ​(X×S,𝒪).tensor-product𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆tensor-productℒℳsuperscript𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ1superscript𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℳ1𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆𝒪\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}\otimes\mathcal{M})\otimes(\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}))^{-1}\otimes(\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{M}))^{-1}\otimes\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{O}).
Proof.

We are comparing two line bundles on the product Pic⁡(X)×Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X). It was shown in the proof of Lemma 6.4.2 that any function on Rat⁡(X)Rat𝑋\operatorname{Rat}(X) is constant, so it suffices to identify these line bundles after restriction along

Pic⁡(X)×Gr⁡(X)⟶Pic⁡(X)×Pic⁡(X).⟶Pic𝑋Gr𝑋Pic𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Gr}(X)\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X).

Furthermore, we saw in the proof of Lemma 6.2.1 that

|Ran∙×Gr(D)Ran|⟶~Gr(X),|\operatorname{Ran}^{\bullet}\times\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}|\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{Gr}(X),

whence it is enough to produce a RanRan\operatorname{Ran}-equivariant isomorphism between the two line bundles after restriction along

Pic(X)×Gr(D)Ran⟶Pic(X)×Gr(X).\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Gr}(X).

Fix xI:S→XI:subscript𝑥𝐼→𝑆superscript𝑋𝐼x_{I}:S\to X^{I}, a line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S, and a divisor Z𝑍Z relative to S𝑆S supported on DxIsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼D_{x_{I}}. Recall that we have a canonical isomorphism

⟨ℒ,𝒪​(Z)⟩X​⟶~​⟨ℒ|DxI,Z]DRansubscriptℒ𝒪𝑍𝑋~⟶subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑍subscript𝐷Ran\langle\mathcal{L},\mathcal{O}(Z)\rangle_{X}\tilde{\longrightarrow}\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x_{I}}},Z]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}

(cf. Proposition 6.5.1).

In order to relate ⟨ℒ|DxI,Z]DRansubscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑍subscript𝐷Ran\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x_{I}}},Z]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}} to the desired determinant formula, we use a Čech resolution in the form of the triangle

R​Γ​(X×S,ℒ)⟶Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ)⊕Γ​(DxI,ℒ)⟶Γ​(D̊xI,ℒ),⟶𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒdirect-sumΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ⟶Γsubscript̊𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒR\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L})\longrightarrow\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})\oplus\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L})\longrightarrow\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),

which is exact by the Beauville-Laszlo theorem. By Lemma 8.1.1 we obtain an isomorphism

det(Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ))​⟶~​detR​Γ​(X×S,ℒ).Γ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ~⟶𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ\det(\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))\tilde{\longrightarrow}\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}). (8.1.1)

Recall that by Proposition 4.7.1, we have

⟨ℒ|DxI,Z]DRan=det(Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ​(Z)))−1⊗det(Γ​(DxI,𝒪),Γ​(DxI,𝒪​(Z))).subscriptevaluated-atℒsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝑍subscript𝐷Rantensor-productsuperscriptΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍1Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝒪Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼𝒪𝑍\langle\mathcal{L}|_{D_{x_{I}}},Z]_{D_{\operatorname{Ran}}}=\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)))^{-1}\otimes\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{O}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{O}(Z))).

Using the aforementioned Čech resolution, we find that

det(Γ(DxI,\displaystyle\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}}, ℒ),Γ(DxI,ℒ(Z)))\displaystyle\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)))
=det(Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ))⊗det(Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ),Γ​(DxI,ℒ​(Z)))absenttensor-productΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍\displaystyle=\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))\otimes\det(\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)))
=det(Γ​(DxI,ℒ),Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ))⊗det(Γ​((X×S)∖ΓxI,ℒ​(Z)),Γ​(DxI,ℒ​(Z)))absenttensor-productΓsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒΓ𝑋𝑆subscriptΓsubscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍Γsubscript𝐷subscript𝑥𝐼ℒ𝑍\displaystyle=\det(\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}),\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}))\otimes\det(\Gamma((X\times S)\setminus\Gamma_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)),\Gamma(D_{x_{I}},\mathcal{L}(Z)))
=det(R​Γ​(X×S,ℒ))⊗(detR​Γ​(X×S,ℒ​(Z)))−1.absenttensor-product𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒsuperscript𝑅Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ𝑍1\displaystyle=\det(R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}))\otimes(\det R\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}(Z)))^{-1}.

Thus we have given the desired formula for the pairing on Pic(X)×Gr(D)Ran\operatorname{Pic}(X)\times\operatorname{Gr}(D)_{\operatorname{Ran}}. The RanRan\operatorname{Ran}-equivariance follows from the compatibility of the Čech resolution with refinement of the covering. ∎

8.2   

We now introduce a formula for ⟨,]X\langle\,,\,]_{X} in the case where X𝑋X is affine. Let I𝐼I denote the set of closed points in X¯∖X¯𝑋𝑋\overline{X}\setminus X. We will use the notations

DI,S:=⨆x∈IDx,S​ and ​D̊I,S:=⨆x∈ID̊x,S.assignsubscript𝐷𝐼𝑆subscriptsquare-union𝑥𝐼subscript𝐷𝑥𝑆 and subscript̊𝐷𝐼𝑆assignsubscriptsquare-union𝑥𝐼subscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆D_{I,S}:=\bigsqcup_{x\in I}D_{x,S}\text{ and }\mathring{D}_{I,S}:=\bigsqcup_{x\in I}\mathring{D}_{x,S}.

Fix S𝑆S-points of Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X) and Pic⁡(X,∂X)Pic𝑋𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X), which are respectively an extendable line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S and a line bundle ℳℳ\mathcal{M} on X×S𝑋𝑆X\times S together with a trivialization α𝛼\alpha of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} over D̊I,Ssubscript̊𝐷𝐼𝑆\mathring{D}_{I,S}. We obtain an isomorphism of Tate vector bundles

Γ​(D̊I,S,ℒ)→idℒ⊗αΓ​(D̊I,S,ℒ⊗ℳ).tensor-productsubscriptidℒ𝛼→Γsubscript̊𝐷𝐼𝑆ℒΓsubscript̊𝐷𝐼𝑆tensor-productℒℳ\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{I,S},\mathcal{L})\xrightarrow{\operatorname{id}_{\mathcal{L}}\otimes\alpha}\Gamma(\mathring{D}_{I,S},\mathcal{L}\otimes\mathcal{M}).

In particular, by comparing under this isomorphism we may form the relative determinant of the colattices Γ​(X×S,ℒ)Γ𝑋𝑆ℒ\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}) and Γ​(X×S,ℒ⊗ℳ)Γ𝑋𝑆tensor-productℒℳ\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}\otimes\mathcal{M}).

Theorem 8.2.1.

For X𝑋X affine, the line bundle ⟨ℒ,(ℳ,α)]Xsubscriptℒℳ𝛼𝑋\langle\mathcal{L},(\mathcal{M},\alpha)]_{X} on S𝑆S is naturally isomorphic to

det((idℒ⊗α)​(Γ​(X×S,ℒ)),Γ​(X×S,ℒ⊗ℳ))−1⊗det(α​(Γ​(X×S,𝒪)),Γ​(X×S,ℳ)).tensor-productsuperscripttensor-productsubscriptidℒ𝛼Γ𝑋𝑆ℒΓ𝑋𝑆tensor-productℒℳ1𝛼Γ𝑋𝑆𝒪Γ𝑋𝑆ℳ\det\big{(}(\operatorname{id}_{\mathcal{L}}\otimes\alpha)(\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L})),\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}\otimes\mathcal{M})\big{)}^{-1}\otimes\det\big{(}\alpha(\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{O})),\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{M})\big{)}.
Proof.

Since we are trying to compare two line bundles on Pic⁡(X,∂X)×Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X), it therefore suffices to construct a Gr⁡(DI)Grsubscript𝐷𝐼\operatorname{Gr}(D_{I})-equivariant isomorphism after restriction along the Gr⁡(DI)Grsubscript𝐷𝐼\operatorname{Gr}(D_{I})-torsor

Pic⁡(X,∂X)×Pic⁡(X¯)⟶Pic⁡(X,∂X)×Pic⁡(X).⟶Pic𝑋𝑋Pic¯𝑋Pic𝑋𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(\overline{X})\longrightarrow\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X).

So suppose we are given an extension ℒ¯¯ℒ\overline{\mathcal{L}} of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} to X¯×S¯𝑋𝑆\overline{X}\times S. We also write ℳ¯¯ℳ\overline{\mathcal{M}} for the the extension of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} obtained using α𝛼\alpha, so that α𝛼\alpha extends to a trivialization of ℳ¯¯ℳ\overline{\mathcal{M}} over DI,Ssubscript𝐷𝐼𝑆D_{I,S}. The isomorphism 8.1.1 therefore gives rise to an isomorphism

det((idℒ⊗α)(Γ(\displaystyle\det\big{(}(\operatorname{id}_{\mathcal{L}}\otimes\alpha)(\Gamma( X×S,ℒ)),Γ(X×S,ℒ⊗ℳ))\displaystyle X\times S,\mathcal{L})),\Gamma(X\times S,\mathcal{L}\otimes\mathcal{M})\big{)}

Thus, by Theorem 8.1.2 we obtain the desired isomorphism of line bundles on Pic⁡(X,∂X)×Pic⁡(X)Pic𝑋𝑋Pic𝑋\operatorname{Pic}(X,\partial X)\times\operatorname{Pic}(X). Tracing through the construction of the isomorphism, one finds that it is Gr⁡(DI)Grsubscript𝐷𝐼\operatorname{Gr}(D_{I})-equivariant as needed. ∎

9 Geometric class field theory

9.1   

In this section we prove Theorem 2.4.1. We will need a couple of technical lemmas. Let p𝑝p denote the characteristic of k𝑘k. Fix a closed point x𝑥x in X𝑋X.

Lemma 9.1.1.

For n𝑛n prime to p𝑝p, the pullback map

H1​(S,𝔾m)​[n]⟶H1​(D̊x,S,𝔾m)​[n]⟶superscript𝐻1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝐻1subscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚delimited-[]𝑛H^{1}(S,\mathbb{G}_{m})[n]\longrightarrow H^{1}(\mathring{D}_{x,S},\mathbb{G}_{m})[n]

is an isomorphism.

Proof.

The multiplication by n𝑛n map ℤ→ℤ→ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}\to\mathbb{Z} induces a long exact sequence on fppf (here equivalent to étale) cohomology

0⟶H0​(S,ℤ)⟶H0​(S,ℤ)⟶H0​(S,ℤ/n​ℤ)⟶H1​(S,ℤ)⟶⋯⟶0superscript𝐻0𝑆ℤ⟶superscript𝐻0𝑆ℤ⟶superscript𝐻0𝑆ℤ𝑛ℤ⟶superscript𝐻1𝑆ℤ⟶⋯0\longrightarrow H^{0}(S,\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow H^{0}(S,\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow H^{0}(S,\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow H^{1}(S,\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow\cdots

Since for A𝐴A a discrete abelian group H0​(S,A)superscript𝐻0𝑆𝐴H^{0}(S,A) classifies locally constant maps S→A→𝑆𝐴S\to A, the map

H0​(S,ℤ)⟶H0​(S,ℤ/n​ℤ)⟶superscript𝐻0𝑆ℤsuperscript𝐻0𝑆ℤ𝑛ℤH^{0}(S,\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow H^{0}(S,\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})

is surjective. Hence H1​(S,ℤ)superscript𝐻1𝑆ℤH^{1}(S,\mathbb{Z}) is n𝑛n-torsion free.

Now by Section 3.13.13.1 in [6], we have an isomorphism

H1​(D̊x,S,𝔾m)​⟶~​H1​(S,ℤ)⊕H1​(𝔸1×S,𝔾m)0⊕H1​(S,𝔾m),direct-sumsuperscript𝐻1subscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚~⟶superscript𝐻1𝑆ℤsuperscript𝐻1subscriptsuperscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚0superscript𝐻1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚H^{1}(\mathring{D}_{x,S},\mathbb{G}_{m})\tilde{\longrightarrow}H^{1}(S,\mathbb{Z})\oplus H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mathbb{G}_{m})_{0}\oplus H^{1}(S,\mathbb{G}_{m}),

where H1​(𝔸1×S,𝔾m)0superscript𝐻1subscriptsuperscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚0H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mathbb{G}_{m})_{0} is the subgroup of line bundles on 𝔸1×Ssuperscript𝔸1𝑆\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S whose restriction to {0}×S0𝑆\{0\}\times S is trivializable. We have seen that H1​(S,ℤ)​[n]=0superscript𝐻1𝑆ℤdelimited-[]𝑛0H^{1}(S,\mathbb{Z})[n]=0, so it remains to show that H1​(𝔸1×S,𝔾m)0superscript𝐻1subscriptsuperscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚0H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mathbb{G}_{m})_{0} is n𝑛n-torsion free. The boundary map attached to the Kummer sequence yields a surjection

H1​(𝔸1×S,μn)⟶H1​(𝔸1×S,𝔾m)​[n],⟶superscript𝐻1superscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝐻1superscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚delimited-[]𝑛H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mu_{n})\longrightarrow H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mathbb{G}_{m})[n],

and since p𝑝p does not divide n𝑛n, we have μn≅ℤ/n​ℤsubscript𝜇𝑛ℤ𝑛ℤ\mu_{n}\cong\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} and

It follows that H1​(𝔸1×S,𝔾m)0​[n]=1superscript𝐻1subscriptsuperscript𝔸1𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚0delimited-[]𝑛1H^{1}(\mathbb{A}^{1}\times S,\mathbb{G}_{m})_{0}[n]=1. ∎

Lemma 9.1.2.

The inclusion

Hom¯⁡(μpk,Pic⁡(D̊x))⟶Hom¯⁡(μpk,Map¯⁡(D̊x,B​𝔾m))⟶¯Homsubscript𝜇superscript𝑝𝑘Picsubscript̊𝐷𝑥¯Homsubscript𝜇superscript𝑝𝑘¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\mu_{p^{k}},\operatorname{Pic}(\mathring{D}_{x}))\longrightarrow\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\mu_{p^{k}},\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},B\mathbb{G}_{m}))

is an isomorphism.

Proof.

A homomorphism μpk×S→Map¯⁡(D̊x,B​𝔾m)×S→subscript𝜇superscript𝑝𝑘𝑆¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆\mu_{p^{k}}\times S\to\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},B\mathbb{G}_{m})\times S over S𝑆S is in particular a map μpk×S→Map¯⁡(D̊x,B​𝔾m)→subscript𝜇superscript𝑝𝑘𝑆¯Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑥𝐵subscript𝔾𝑚\mu_{p^{k}}\times S\to\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(\mathring{D}_{x},B\mathbb{G}_{m}) whose restriction to {1}×S1𝑆\{1\}\times S is the trivial bundle. Since

D̊x,S⟶D̊x,μpk×S⟶subscript̊𝐷𝑥𝑆subscript̊𝐷𝑥subscript𝜇superscript𝑝𝑘𝑆\mathring{D}_{x,S}\longrightarrow\mathring{D}_{x,\mu_{p^{k}}\times S}

is a nilpotent embedding and 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚\mathbb{G}_{m} is smooth, the trivialization extends. Hence the bundle is trivializable, and in particular extendable. ∎

9.2   

We are now in a position to prove the theorem.

Proof of Theorem 2.4.1.

Note that the isomorphism for D̊xsubscript̊𝐷𝑥\mathring{D}_{x} implies the one for X𝑋X. Letting I𝐼I denote the set of closed points in X¯∖X¯𝑋𝑋\overline{X}\setminus X, this follows from the Cartesian square

One also reduces immediately to the case that A=ℤ/n​ℤ𝐴ℤ𝑛ℤA=\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} is cyclic. Thus we are trying to prove that

Appendix A The ramified local Abel-Jacobi map

A.1

Thus we obtain a canonical map

HomS⁡(𝔏​𝔾m×S,G×S)⟶Map⁡((𝔏​𝔾m×S)aff,G).⟶subscriptHom𝑆𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆𝐺𝑆Mapsuperscript𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆aff𝐺\operatorname{Hom}_{S}(\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S,G\times S)\longrightarrow\operatorname{Map}((\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S)^{\operatorname{aff}},G). (A.3.1)

Finally, we consider the composition

HomS⁡(𝔏​𝔾m×S,G×S)→(A.3.1)Map⁡((𝔏​𝔾m×S)aff,G)⟶Map⁡(D̊S,G),A.3.1→subscriptHom𝑆𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆𝐺𝑆Mapsuperscript𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚𝑆aff𝐺⟶Mapsubscript̊𝐷𝑆𝐺\operatorname{Hom}_{S}(\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S,G\times S)\xrightarrow{(\ref{oblvalb})}\operatorname{Map}((\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\times S)^{\operatorname{aff}},G)\longrightarrow\operatorname{Map}(\mathring{D}_{S},G),

where the second map is precomposition with AJD̊SsubscriptAJsubscript̊𝐷𝑆\operatorname{AJ}_{\mathring{D}_{S}}. This is easily seen to be natural in S𝑆S and hence induces

Hom¯​(𝔏​𝔾m,G)⟶Map¯​(D̊,G).⟶¯Hom𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚𝐺¯Map̊𝐷𝐺\underline{\operatorname{Hom}}(\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m},G)\longrightarrow\underline{\operatorname{Map}}(\mathring{D},G). (A.3.2)

On the other hand, we have the perfect pairing (2.3.1) arising as the commutator in the Tate extension.

Proposition A.3.2.

When G=𝔾m𝐺subscript𝔾𝑚G=\mathbb{G}_{m}, the map (A.3.2) is inverse to the isomorphism induced by the pairing (2.3.1).

Proof.

First observe that we have an isomorphism of short exact sequences

where the left and right vertical isomorphisms are induced by the pairing [,⟩D[\,,\,\rangle_{D}. Namely, this results from the diagram in the proof of Theorem 5.4.1 by restricting to x𝑥x and rotating the rows.

To prove the proposition, it therefore suffices to prove that the diagram

commutes, where the left and right vertical maps are inverse to those in the previous diagram. By Theorem 5.2.1, the left vertical map agrees with restriction along AJDsubscriptAJ𝐷\operatorname{AJ}_{D}, and therefore the left square commutes because the square (A.2.2) does.

As for the right square, fix a coordinate t𝑡t at x𝑥x, which induces a splitting of the projection 𝔏​𝔾m→Gr→𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚Gr\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\to\operatorname{Gr} and hence 𝔏​𝔾maff≅aff⁡(Gr)×𝔏+​𝔾m𝔏superscriptsubscript𝔾𝑚affaffGrsuperscript𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}^{\operatorname{aff}}\cong\operatorname{aff}(\operatorname{Gr})\times\mathfrak{L}^{+}\mathbb{G}_{m}. Observe that the resulting composition

D̊→AJD̊𝔏​𝔾maff⟶𝔏+​𝔾msubscriptAJ̊𝐷→̊𝐷𝔏superscriptsubscript𝔾𝑚aff⟶superscript𝔏subscript𝔾𝑚\mathring{D}\xrightarrow{\operatorname{AJ}_{\mathring{D}}}\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}^{\operatorname{aff}}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}^{+}\mathbb{G}_{m} (A.3.3)

is the invertible function on D×D̊𝐷̊𝐷D\times\mathring{D} given by the series t−u𝑡𝑢t-u (as we previously observed, this is a unit with inverse given by the formula (A.2.1)). The claim now amounts to showing that the composition

Gr→[,⟩D𝔏+​𝔾m∗⟶𝔏​𝔾m⟶Gr\operatorname{Gr}\xrightarrow{[\,,\,\rangle_{D}}\mathfrak{L}^{+}\mathbb{G}_{m}^{*}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{L}\mathbb{G}_{m}\longrightarrow\operatorname{Gr} (A.3.4)

is the identity, where the second map is given by restriction along (A.3.3). Note that Theorem 5.2.1 implies that restriction along AJDsubscriptAJ𝐷\operatorname{AJ}_{D} induces an isomorphism

Hom¯⁡(Gr,Gr)​⟶~​Map¯⁡(D,Gr),¯HomGrGr~⟶¯Map𝐷Gr\operatorname{\underline{Hom}}(\operatorname{Gr},\operatorname{Gr})\tilde{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\underline{Map}}(D,\operatorname{Gr}),

so it suffices to check that (A.3.4) is the identity after precomposition with AJDsubscriptAJ𝐷\operatorname{AJ}_{D}. Given f:S→D:𝑓→𝑆𝐷f:S\to D, which is just a nilpotent function on S𝑆S, the resulting element of 𝔏+​𝔾m∗superscript𝔏superscriptsubscript𝔾𝑚\mathfrak{L}^{+}\mathbb{G}_{m}^{*} is given by evaluation at f𝑓f. Precomposing with (A.3.4) yields the function t−f:D̊S→𝔾m:𝑡𝑓→subscript̊𝐷𝑆subscript𝔾𝑚t-f:\mathring{D}_{S}\to\mathbb{G}_{m}, whose image in GrGr\operatorname{Gr} is AJD⁡(f)subscriptAJ𝐷𝑓\operatorname{AJ}_{D}(f) as desired. ∎
